PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Fairway, Kansas. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the Prior Code as amended through April 14, 2014. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the Prior Code, as amended, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers or by using the decimal system. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up to date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Roger D. Merriam, Senior Code Attorney, and Andrea Gill, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to the City staff for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the City readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the City's affairs.

CITY OF FAIRWAY, KANSAS 
ORDINANCE NO. 1581 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE CITY OF FAIRWAY, KANSAS; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING THE CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN THIS CODE AND ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
    BE IT ORDAINED BY THE GOVERNING BODY OF THE CITY OF FAIRWAY, KANSAS: 
Section 1. The Code entitled "Code of Ordinances, City of Fairway, Kansas," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 15, each inclusive, is adopted. The codification was authorized by ordinance, and was made in conformity with K.S.A. 12-3014 and 12-3015, and amendments thereto. 
Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before February 10, 2014, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
Section 3. The repeal provided for in Section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a later passed ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished as provided in Section 1-7 of this Code. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not that penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the City may pursue other remedies, such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code, when passed in a form as to indicate an intention to make it a part of the Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
Section 6. Ordinances adopted after April 14, 2014, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
Section 7. This ordinance shall take effect upon its publication in an official City newspaper. 
Passed by the City Council on November 10, 2014. Approved by the Mayor. 
Attest: 
___________ 
Jerry Wiley, Mayor 
___________ 
Kathy A. Axelson, City Clerk

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The chapters and sections herein shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Fairway, Kansas," and may be so cited. Such Code may also be cited as the "Fairway City Code." 
State Law reference- Ordinance codification, K.S.A. 12-3014 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    The following definitions and rules of construction shall apply to this Code and to all ordinances and resolutions unless the context requires otherwise: 
    Generally. When provisions conflict, the specific shall prevail over the general. All provisions shall be liberally construed so that the intent of the City Council may be effectuated. Terms and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical terms, technical phrases and terms and phrases that have acquired peculiar and appropriate meanings in law shall be construed according to such meanings. 
    Chief of Police. The term "Chief of Police" means the City-Marshal-Chief of Police. 
    City . The term "City" means the City of Fairway, Kansas. 
    City Council. The term "City Council" means that body consisting of eight (8) members, two (2) from each of the City's four (4) wards. 
    Code . The term "Code" means the Code of Ordinances, City of Fairway, Kansas, as designated in Section 1-1. 
    Computation of time . In computing any period of time prescribed or allowed by this Code, the day of the act, event, or default from which the designated period of time begins to run shall not be included. The last day of the period so computed is to be included, unless it is a Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, in which event the period runs until the end of the next day which is not a Saturday, a Sunday or a legal holiday. When the period of time prescribed or allowed is less than eleven (11) days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. A half holiday shall be considered as other days and not as a holiday. The term "legal holiday" includes any day designated as a holiday by the Congress of the United States, by the legislature of this State, or by the City. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, K.S.A. 60-206. 
    Conjunctions . In a provision involving two (2) or more items, conditions, provisions or events, which items, conditions, provisions or events are connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either ... or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows, except that when appropriate from the context, the terms "and" and "or" are interchangeable: 
(1)  The term "and" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply. 
(2)  The term "or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly or in any combination. 
(3)  The term "either ... or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly but not in combination. 
    County . The term "County" means Johnson County, Kansas. 
    Delegation of authority . A provision that authorizes or requires a City officer or City employee to perform an act or make a decision authorizes such officer or employee to act or make a decision through subordinates. 
    Following . The term "following" means next after. 
    Gender . Terms of one (1) gender include all other genders. 
    Governing Body . The term "Governing Body" means that body consisting of the Mayor and City Council. 
    In the City. The term "in the City" means and includes all territory over which the City now has, or shall hereafter acquire jurisdiction for the exercise of its police powers or other regulatory powers. 
    Includes . The term "includes" does not limit a term to a specified example. 
    Joint authority . Terms giving a joint authority to three (3) or more persons give such authority to a majority of such persons. 
    K.S.A. The abbreviation "K.S.A." means the Kansas Statutes Annotated, as amended. 
    May . The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive and not mandatory. 
    May not . The term "may not" states a prohibition. 
    Month . The term "month" means a calendar month. 
    Must . The term "must" shall be construed as being mandatory. 
    Number . Terms in the singular include the plural. Terms in the plural include the singular. 
    Oath . A solemn affirmation is the equivalent to an oath, and a person shall be deemed to have sworn if such person makes such an affirmation. 
    Officers, departments, etc. References to officers, departments, board, commissions or employees are to City officers, City departments, City boards, City commissions and City employees. 
    Owner . The term "owner," as applied to property, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or part of such property. 
    Person . The term "person" means any human being, any governmental or political subdivision or public agency, any public or private corporation, any partnership, any firm, association or other organization, any receiver, trustee, assignee, agent, or other legal representative of any of the foregoing or any other legal entity. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" means any property other than real property. 
    Preceding . The term "preceding" means next before. 
    Premises . The term "premises," as applied to real property, includes land and structures. 
    Property . The term "property" includes real property, personal property and mixed property. 
    Real property, real estate, land, lands . The terms "real property," "real estate" and "land" include lands, buildings, tenements and hereditaments and all rights and interests therein except chattel interests. 
    Right-of-way. The term "right-of-way" means a strip of land acquired by reservation, dedication, prescription, or condemnation for public use and intended to be occupied by a street, bike path, alley, walkway, crosswalk, electric transmission line, cable/fiber, oil or gas pipeline, water line, sanitary storm sewer, or other similar uses. It normally incorporates the curbs, lawn strips, lighting, and drainage facilities, and may include special features (required by the topography or treatment), such as grade separation, landscaped areas, viaducts, and bridges. The interest acquired may be a full fee interest or an easement interest. 
    Roadway . The term "roadway" means that portion of a street improved or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
    Shall . The term "shall" is to be construed as being mandatory. 
    Signature and subscription by mark. The terms "signature" and "subscription" include a mark when the signer or subscriber cannot write. In such situations, such person's name shall be written near the mark by a witness who writes his own name near such person's name. 
    State . The term "State" means the State of Kansas. 
    Street . The term "street" means any alley, avenue, boulevard, highway, road, lane, viaduct, bridge and the approach thereto, and any other public thoroughfare in the City. The term "street" also means the entire width thereof between abutting property lines and includes a sidewalk or footpath. 
    Tenant, occupant . The terms "tenant" and "occupant," as applied to a building or land, include: 
(1)  Any person holding, either alone or with others, a written or oral lease of such building or land. 
(2)  Any person, who either alone or with others, occupies such building or land. 
    Tense . The present tense includes the past and future tenses. The future tense includes the present tense. 
    Writing . The term "writing" includes any form of recorded message capable of comprehension by ordinary visual means. Whenever any notice, report, statement or record is authorized or required, it shall be made in writing in the English language. 
    Year . The term "year" means a calendar year. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes; references. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and are not titles of such sections, or of any part of the section, nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when any such section, including the catchline, is amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history or source notes appearing in parenthesis after sections in this Code have no legal effect and only indicate legislative history. Editor's notes, cross references and State law references that appear in this Code after sections or subsections or that otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of the Code and have no legal effect. 
(c)  Unless specified otherwise, all references to chapters or sections are to chapters or sections of this Code. 
Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  Unless specifically provided otherwise, the repeal of an ordinance does not revive any previously repealed ordinance. 
(b)  The repeal or amendment of an ordinance does not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor does such repeal or amendment affect any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the amendment or repeal. 
Sec. 1-5. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances adopted subsequent to this Code that amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of the Code and printed for inclusion in the Code. Portions of this Code repealed by subsequent ordinances may be excluded from this Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. 
(b)  Amendments to provisions of this Code may be made with the following language: "Section (Chapter, Article, Division or Subdivision, as appropriate) _____ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Fairway, Kansas, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." 
(c)  If a new section, subdivision, division, article or chapter is to be added to the Code, the following language may be used: "Section (Chapter, Article, Division or Subdivision, as appropriate) _____ of the of Ordinances, City of Fairway, Kansas, is hereby created to read as follows:...." 
(d)  All provisions desired to be repealed should be repealed specifically by section, subdivision, division, article or chapter number, as appropriate, or by setting out the repealed provisions in full in the repealing ordinance. 
Sec. 1-6. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  Supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the City. A supplement to this Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances of a general and permanent nature adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of the supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete. The new pages shall be so prepared that when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the person authorized to prepare the supplement may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts or ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as necessary to do so in order to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the person may: 
(1)  Arrange the material into appropriate organizational units. 
(2)  Supply appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions and sections to be included in the Code and make changes in any such catchlines, headings and titles or in any such catchlines, headings and titles already in the Code. 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions and sections to be added to the Code. 
(4)  Where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing numbers assigned to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections. 
(5)  Change the terms "this ordinance" or similar words to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," "this subdivision," "this section" or "Sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code that embody the substantive provisions of the ordinance incorporated in the Code). 
(6)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of the ordinances inserted in the Code. 
Sec. 1-7. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  In this section, the term "violation of this Code" means any of the following: 
(1)  Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(2)  Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(3)  Failure to perform an act if the failure is prohibited or is made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(4)  Counseling, aiding or abetting a violation of this Code as set forth in Subsections (a)(1) through (a)(3) of this section. 
(b)  In this section the term "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a City officer or City employee to perform an official duty unless it is specifically provided that the failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section. 
(c)  For the purpose of sentencing, unless otherwise specified in this Code, the following classes of violations of this Code and the punishment and terms of confinement authorized for each class are established: 
(1)  Class A violation, the sentence for which shall be a definite term of confinement in the County jail which shall be fixed by the Court and shall not exceed one (1) year; 
(2)  Class B violation, the sentence for which shall be a definite term of confinement in the County jail which shall be fixed by the Court and shall not exceed six (6) months; 
(3)  Class C violation, the sentence for which shall be a definite term of confinement in the County jail which shall be fixed by the Court and shall not exceed one (1) month; and 
(4)  Unclassified violations, which shall include all offenses declared to be violations without specification as to class, the sentence for which shall be in accordance with the sentence specified in the section that defines the offense; if no penalty is provided, the sentence shall be the same penalty as provided in this section for a Class C violation. 
(d)  Fine in lieu of confinement. 
(1)  A person convicted of a violation of this Code may, in addition to, or instead of, the confinement authorized by law, be sentenced to pay a fine which shall be fixed by the Court, unless otherwise specified in this Code, as follows: 
a.  Class A violation, a sum not exceeding two thousand and five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
b.  Class B violation, a sum not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
c.  Class C violation, a sum not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
d.  Unclassified violation, any sum authorized by the section that defines the offense. If no penalty is provided for same, the fine shall not exceed the fine provided in this section for a Class C violation. 
(2)  As an alternative to Subsection (d)(1) of this section, the fine imposed may be fixed at any greater sum not exceeding double the pecuniary gain derived from the offense by the offender. 
(e)  Except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance: 
(1)  With respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day that the violation continues is a separate offense. 
(2)  With respect to all other violations of this Code, each act constitutes a separate offense. 
(f)  The imposition of a penalty hereunder does not prevent suspension or revocation of a license or a permit, or other administrative sanctions. 
(g)  Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent injunctive relief. 
Sec. 1-8. - Severability. 
    The sections, subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code and all provisions adopted by reference in this Code are severable so that if any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause and phrase of this Code or of any provision adopted by reference in this Code is declared unconstitutional or invalid by a valid judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction, such judgment shall not affect the validity of any other section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause and phrase of this Code or of any provision adopted by reference in this Code, for the City Council declares that it is its intent that it would have enacted this Code and all provisions adopted by reference in this Code without such invalid or unconstitutional provisions. If any provision of this Code is declared to be inapplicable to specific property by a valid judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction, such judgment shall not restrict the applicability of such provision to other property. 
Sec. 1-9. - Provisions deemed continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions of this Code, insofar as they are substantially the same as legislation previously adopted by the City relating to the same subject matter, shall be construed as restatements and continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-10. - Code does not affect prior offenses or rights. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code affects any offense or act committed or done, any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code does not authorize any use or the continuation of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance on the effective date of this Code. 
Sec. 1-11. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code affects the validity of any Charter ordinance or any of the following ordinances or portions of ordinances not found in this Code. Such ordinances continue in full force and effect to the same extent as if published at length in this Code. 
(1)  Any ordinance annexing property into the City, deannexing property or excluding property from the City or describing the corporate limits. 
(2)  Any ordinance providing for salaries or other employee benefits not codified in this Code. 
(3)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness. 
(4)  Any ordinance authorizing or approving any contract, deed, or agreement. 
(5)  Any ordinance making or approving any appropriation or budget. 
(6)  Any ordinance granting any right or franchise. 
(7)  Any ordinance vacating any easement or park land. 
(8)  Any ordinance adopting or amending the comprehensive plan. 
(9)  Any ordinance levying or imposing any special assessment. 
(10)  Any ordinance dedicating, establishing naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street. 
(11)  Any ordinance establishing the grade of any street or sidewalk. 
(12)  Any ordinance dedicating, accepting or vacating any plat or subdivision. 
(13)  Any ordinance levying, imposing or otherwise relating to taxes. 
(14)  Any ordinance rezoning specific property. 
(15)  Any ordinance that is temporary, although general in effect. 
(16)  Any ordinance that is special, although permanent in effect. 
(17)  Any ordinance the purpose of which has been accomplished. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Compliance with statute. 
    Business of the City shall be conducted by State statute except as may be altered by Charter ordinance or augmented by this Code. 
Editor's note- Issues of administration are covered in K.S.A. chs. 12 and 14 and in Charter ordinances. 
Secs. 2-2-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY GOVERNING BODY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Adoption of ordinances, K.S.A. 12-3001 et seq.; quorum, K.S.A. 14-111; Mayor generally, K.S.A. 13-301 et seq.; president of council and other officers, K.S.A. 11-204. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-21. - Resolutions and motions, passage. 
(a)  A motion regarding a Charter ordinance may be acted upon at a duly noticed meeting at which a majority of the Governing Body is in attendance. The Mayor and each Councilmember shall each have one (1) vote when in attendance at such meeting and the affirmative vote of two-thirds (?) of the full membership of the Governing Body is required for passage. 
(b)  A motion regarding any other ordinance may be acted upon at a duly noticed meeting at which a majority of the members of the City Council is in attendance. Each Councilmember shall have one (1) vote when in attendance at such meeting and the affirmative vote of a majority of the full membership of the City Council is required for passage. If the favorable vote is one (1) less than the number required for passage, the Mayor shall have the power to cast the deciding vote in favor of the ordinance. Any ordinance that is vetoed by the Mayor may be passed over the veto by a vote of three-fourths (3/4) of the full membership of the City Council. 
(c)  Any other resolution or motion requiring the approval of the City Council or the Governing Body may be considered at a duly noticed meeting of the City Council at which a majority of the members of the City Council is in attendance. When passage requires the affirmative vote of a simple majority of the Councilmembers in attendance, the Mayor shall vote only in the event of a tie. It the affirmative vote of a greater number of the Councilmembers in attendance is required, the Mayor may cast the deciding vote when the number of favorable votes is one (1) less than the required number. 
(d)  Attendance at a meeting may be in person or it may be by telephone or other means that allows the person so attending to hear and be heard by all other persons in attendance at the meeting. 
(Prior Code, § 1-104; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1679 , § 1, 11-13-2018; Ord. No. 1683 , § 1, 1-30-2019) 
Sec. 2-22. - Time of regular meetings. 
    Regular meetings of the City Council shall be held on the second Monday of each month at 7:30 p.m.; provided that, when a regular meeting day shall fall on any legal holiday, that regular meeting shall be held on the succeeding day not observed as a holiday. 
(Prior Code, § 1-105; Ord. No. 125, § 1; Ord. No. 1218; Ord. No. 1440) 
Sec. 2-23. - Conduct of meeting. 
    The Mayor or, in the absence of the Mayor, the President of the City Council shall preside over any meeting of the City Council. In the event that neither the Mayor nor the President of the City Council is present at any regular or special meeting of the City Council, the members of the City Council that are in attendance shall select from their number a person to preside over the meeting until the arrival of either the Mayor or the President of the City Council. Any member of the City Council shall retain the voting status of a member of the City Council while presiding over any regular or special meeting of the City Council. 
(Prior Code, § 1-105; Ord. No. 125, § 1; Ord. No. 1218; Ord. No. 1440) 
State Law reference- Presiding officer, K.S.A. 14-204, 14-301. 
Sec. 2-24. - Emergency government. 
    In the event of a catastrophe in which all, or a majority of the members of the City Council are fatally injured, the interim City Council shall be composed of the surviving members, the City Attorney, the City Clerk, and a sufficient number of the appointed officials selected in order of the greatest seniority in office to make up a City Council of the prescribed number. 
(Prior Code, § 1-106; Ord. No. 611) 
Secs. 2-25-2-53. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WARDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Wards, K.S.A. 14-103; hours of voting, K.S.A. 25-106. 

Sec. 2-54. - Wards; division of City. 
    The City is hereby divided into four (4) wards designated as the first, second, third, and fourth wards, respectively. 
(Prior Code, § 4-201) 
Sec. 2-55. - First ward. 
    The first ward shall include all of that portion of the City lying north of the centerline of State Park Road and east of the centerline of Falmouth Road. 
(Prior Code, § 4-202; Ord. No. 893) 
Sec. 2-56. - Second ward. 
    The second ward shall include all of that portion of the City lying within the following described boundaries, to wit: 
    Beginning at the center of the intersection of 59th Street and Roe Avenue; 
    Thence east along the centerline of 59th Street to the centerline of Mission Road; 
    Thence north along the centerline of Mission Road to the centerline of Shawnee Mission Parkway; 
    Thence east along the centerline of Shawnee Mission Parkway to its intersection with the centerline of State Park Road; 
    Thence southeast along the centerline of State Park Road to its intersection with the centerline of Falmouth Road; 
    Thence north along the centerline of Falmouth Road to the City limits; 
    Thence west, southwest, and south along the City limits to the center of the intersection of 59th Street and Roe Avenue. 
(Prior Code, § 4-203) 
Sec. 2-57. - Third ward. 
    The third ward shall include all of that portion of the City lying within the following described boundaries, to wit: 
    Beginning at the center of the intersection of Mission Road and Shawnee Mission Parkway; 
    Thence south along the centerline of Mission Road to the centerline of 63rd Street; 
    Thence east along the centerline of 63rd Street to the City limits; 
    Thence north following the City limits to the centerline of State Park Road; 
    Thence northwest along the centerline of State Park Road to the centerline of Shawnee Mission Parkway; 
    Thence west along the centerline of Shawnee Mission Parkway to the center of the intersection of Mission Road and Shawnee Mission Parkway. 
(Prior Code, § 4-204; Ord. No. 895) 
Sec. 2-58. - Fourth ward. 
    The fourth ward shall include all that portion of the City lying south of the centerline of 59th Street and west of the centerline of Mission Road. 
(Prior Code, § 4-205; Ord. No. 229) 
Secs. 2-59-2-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Oaths of office, K.S.A. 154-106, 25-2120. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-90. - Appointment of officers. 
    At the first regular meeting of the City Council in February of each year the Mayor shall appoint the following officers: 
    City Administrator to perform the duties set forth in Code Section 2-93. 
    Municipal Judge of the Municipal Court to perform the duties set forth in KSA 12-4106 as it may be amended from time to time or replaced. 
    City Attorney to perform the duties set forth in Code Section 2-92. 
    City Treasurer to perform the duties set forth in Code Sections 2-145 through 2-177. 
    At that same time, the Mayor may also appoint one (1) or more of the following: 
    Special Zoning Counsel to assist the City Attorney with matters relating to zoning and planning including attending all meetings of the Planning Commission and the Board of Zoning Appeals. 
    City Prosecutor to assist the City Attorney by prosecuting all matters that are brought before the Municipal Court. 
    City Prosecutor Pro-Tem to assume the duties of the City Prosecutor when he or she is incapacitated or otherwise unable to perform the duties. 
    Municipal Court Judge Pro-Tem to assume the duties of the Municipal Judge of the Municipal Court when he or she is incapacitated or otherwise unable to perform the duties. 
    City Engineer to consult with the Public Works Director as necessary regarding public works projects and matters effecting City property. 
    Each of the forgoing appointments shall specify whether the appointee is to be a City employee, an independent contractor, or an unpaid volunteer. The consent of the City Council shall be as provided in Charter Ordinance 26. 
(Ord. No. 1686 , § 1, 1-30-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1686 , §§ 1, 2, adopted January 30, 2019, repealed the former § 2-90, and enacted a new § 2-90 as set out herein. The former § 2-90 pertained to failure to approve an appointment and derived from Prior Code § 1-202 and Ord. No. 611. 
Sec. 2-91. - Failure to act or to approve. 
    If the City Council fails to act within thirty (30) days of an appointment, the appointment shall be deemed approved. The City Council shall approve any such appointment unless it makes a specific finding by the passage of a resolution that the appointee is either unqualified or unfit to hold the office. If the City Council disapproves of a required appointment, the Mayor shall appoint another to the position. 
(Ord. No. 1686 , § 3, 1-30-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1686 , §§ 3, 4, adopted January 30, 2019, repealed the former § 2-91, and enacted a new § 2-91 as set out herein. The former § 2-91 pertained to failure to removal of officers and derived from Prior Code § 1-203; Ord. No. 677 and Ord. No. 1365. 
Sec. 2-92. - City Attorney; duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the City Attorney to attend, so far as reasonably possible, all meetings of the City Council, during his term to furnish advice on legal points to the Mayor, City Council, City officers and employees concerning City business; to aid in drawing ordinances; to draw contracts and such other instruments as may be necessary for City business; to attend hearings before the County Commissioners and the State boards when directed by the Mayor and City Council and to represent the City generally in legal matters. 
(Prior Code, § 1-220; Ord. No. 4; Ord. No. 611) 
Sec. 2-93. - City Administrator. 
(a)  Office of City Administrator established. There is hereby created and established the office of City Administrator for the City. 
(b)  Qualifications. The person appointed to the office of City Administrator shall be a graduate of an accredited university or college, majoring in public administration or shall have the equivalent qualifications and experience. 
(c)  Duties. 
(1)  Administrative office. The City Administrator shall be the chief administrative assistant to the Mayor and City Council. Except as otherwise specified by ordinance or by the law of the State of Kansas, the City Administrator shall coordinate and generally supervise the operation of all departments of the City. 
(2)  Purchasing. The City Administrator shall be the purchasing agent for the City and all purchases shall be made under the direction and supervision of the City Administrator, and all purchases shall be made in accordance with purchasing rules and procedures approved by the City Council. 
(3)  Budget. The City Administrator shall be the budget officer of the City in accordance with Kansas statutes and shall assemble estimates of the financial needs and resources of the City for each ensuing year and shall prepare a program of activities within the financial power of the City, embodying in it a budget document with proper supporting schedules and an analysis to be proposed to the Mayor and the City Council for their final approval. 
(4)  Financial reports. The City Administrator shall make monthly reports to the Mayor and City Council relative to the financial condition of the City. The reports shall show the financial conditions of the City in relation to the budget. 
(5)  Annual report. The City Administrator shall prepare and present to the Mayor and the City Council an annual report of the City's affairs, including in the report a summary of reports of department heads and all other reports as the Mayor and City Council may require. 
(6)  Personnel system. The City Administrator shall act as the personnel officer of the City and shall recommend an appropriate employee compensation plan to the Mayor and City Council and administer an appropriate employee compensation plan, as approved by the Mayor and City Council. The City Administrator shall consult with department heads regarding advancements, pay adjustments, and the appointment or removal (in accordance with personnel polices approved by the City Council) of all subordinate employees of the City. No action listed above shall be taken without the approval of the City Administrator. The City Administrator shall make recommendations to the Mayor regarding the appointment and removal of all appointive officials of the City. For purpose of this section, the term "department heads" shall mean the Director of Public Works, Chief of Police, and Director of Parks and Recreation, and shall further include any additional employee or officer that the Governing Body may designate in the future as a "department head." 
(7)  Policy formulation. The City Administrator shall recommend to the Mayor and City Council adoption of all measures as the City Administrator may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety, or welfare of the City or for the improvement of administrative services for the City. 
(8)  City Council agenda. The City Administrator shall submit a proposed agenda for each council meeting to the Mayor. 
(9)  Boards and committees. The City Administrator shall work with all City boards and committees to help coordinate the work of each. 
(10)  Attend council meetings. The City Administrator shall attend all meetings of the City Council. 
(11)  Bid specifications. All bid specifications for service and equipment shall be coordinated through the City Administrator in accordance with City Council policy. 
(12)  State and Federal aid program. The City Administrator shall coordinate Federal and State programs that may have application to the City. 
(13)  Conference attendance. The City Administrator shall attend State and regional conferences and programs applicable to his or her office, and the business of the City, whenever the attendance is directed and approved by the City Council and the Mayor. 
(14)  Press release. The City Administrator, in conjunction with the Mayor, shall be responsible for keeping the public informed on the purposes and methods of City government through all available news media. 
(15)  Record keeping. The City Administrator shall keep full and accurate records of administrative actions, and shall safely and properly keep all those records and papers. Such records and papers shall be and remain the property of the City and be open to inspection by the Mayor and City Council at all times. 
(16)  Other duties. The City Administrator shall perform all other duties as may be described or amended in any City Administrator job description or employment contract. 
(d)  Powers. 
(1)  City property. The City Administrator shall have responsibility for all real and personal property of the City and all inventories of that property and upkeep of that property. Personal property may be sold only with approval of the City Council. Real property may be sold only with the approval of the City Council, by resolution or ordinance. 
(2)  Implement administrative policies. The City Administrator shall have the power to prescribe such procedures as are necessary or expedient for the implementation of administrative policies as set forth by the governing body. 
(3)  Coordinate departments. The City Administrator shall have responsibility for coordinating the work of all departments of the City, and at times of an emergency, shall have authority to assign the employees of the City to any department where they are needed for the most effective discharge of the functions of City government. 
(4)  Investigate and report. The City Administrator shall have the power to investigate and to examine or inquire into the affairs or operation of any department of the City under the City Administrator's jurisdiction, and shall report on any condition or fact concerning the City government requested by the Mayor or City Council. 
(5)  Appear before the City Council. The City Administrator shall have the power to appear before and address the City Council at any meeting. 
(6)  City Administrator not to supersede lawful action of the Mayor and/or City Council. At no time shall the duties or powers of the City Administrator supersede the lawful action of the Mayor and/or City Council. 
( Ord. No. 1630 , § 2, 9-12-2016; Ord. No. 1684 , § 1, 1-30-2019) 
Sec. 2-94. - Apppointment or employment in more than one position. 
    The same person may be appointed to more than one (1) appointive office, or employed in more than one (1) department, except that the same person shall not be appointed to incompatible offices. Salaries or wages of that person shall be prorated between the proper funds of the several offices or departments. 
( Ord. No. 1630 , § 3, 9-12-2016) 
Secs. 2-95-2-112. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-113. - Office hours; records; correspondence; files. 
    The City Clerk shall keep an office open in the City Hall, which office shall be open at the usual business hours observed in the City. He/she shall be custodian of all the City records, books, files, papers, documents and other personal effects belonging to the City not properly pertaining to any other office. He/she shall keep suitable files and records of all the documents, papers, and other effects pertaining to the business of the City, including all correspondence, deeds, contract bids, petitions and similar official documents, as engineering plans and specifications and an official map of the City. 
(Prior Code, § 1-204; Ord. No. 1645 , § 1, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 2-114. - Meetings; journal; ordinance duties. 
    The City Clerk or his/her designee shall attend all meetings of the Governing Body and the City Council. The City Clerk shall make and keep a record of the proceedings and meetings of the Governing Body and the City Council pertaining to the City's affairs transacted at any such meeting. He/she shall also cause to be published such resolutions, notices and proclamations as may be required by law or by ordinance. 
(Prior Code, § 1-205; Ord. No. 1645 , § 3, 2-13-2017) 
State Law reference- Clerk to keep record of ordinances, K.S.A. 12-3007; publication of ordinances, K.S.A. 12-3008. 
Sec. 2-115. - Seal; records. 
    The City Clerk shall have charge of the Corporate Seal of the City and shall affix the same to the official copy of all ordinances, deeds, contracts, and similar documents required to be authenticated, and he/she shall keep suitable files of all oaths required to be deposited in his office. 
(Prior Code, § 1-206; Ord. No. 1645 , § 5, 2-13-2017) 
State Law reference- Power of clerk to administer oaths, K.S.A. 54-110. 
Sec. 2-116. - Accounting records; funds; levies. 
    The City Clerk or his/her designee shall prepare and keep suitable fiscal accounting records in the form and manner which shall have been approved for minimum accounting standards by the State Municipal Accounting Board. He/she shall prepare, or cause to be prepared, all orders for the purchase of goods and services required by the City and shall make the suitable entries in his books of all such orders and contracts entered into by the City which shall obligate the funds or credit of the City. He/she shall keep a separate account of each of the several funds of the City, whether it be derived from tax money coming to the City or from whatever source derived, and credit all income to the proper fund of the City. The money belonging to one (1) fund shall not be placed to the credit of any other fund or be transferred to another fund unless there is lawful authority for the same and then only in accordance with the directions of the City Council. Each separate tax levy shall constitute a separate fund as provided by law authorizing such levy. 
(Prior Code, § 1-207; Ord. No. 1645 , § 7, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 2-117. - Budget duties. 
    The City Clerk shall render such assistance as may be required in preparing the annual City budget, any ordinance for the levying of taxes, and shall certify the same to the County Clerk in the form and manner required by law together with a copy of the budget. In addition, a copy of the annual City budget shall be filed in the office of the State Department of Post Audits. At the beginning of the budget year, the City Clerk shall open and keep an account of each fund thereof, showing the total amount appropriated for that fund in the budget, the date, number and amount of each warrant and check drawn thereon. He/she shall keep such fiscal records as may be required to show the outstanding contracts or other obligations against any fund of the budget. 
(Prior Code, § 1-208; Ord. No. 1645 , § 9, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 2-118. - Claims; financial reports; warrants. 
    The City Clerk shall receive at his/her office all claims against the City for goods or services rendered, and he shall prepare them in suitable form for the consideration of the City Council at its next succeeding meeting. He/she shall prepare appropriation ordinances for the payment of all claims to be allowed. He shall draw warrants or warrant checks only when appropriation to pay the same has been made by ordinance. His/her accounts shall properly show the amounts paid from any fund of the City and the cash balance existing in each fund. He/she shall prepare a report showing the financial condition of the City each month and present the same to the City Council at its first regular meeting of the succeeding month, the amount paid out of any fund and the outstanding claim authorized to be paid out of all funds of the City so that the Governing Body may not create any debts nor authorize the issuance of warrants in violation of the budget law (K.S.A. 79-2925-79-2937). In no event shall the City Clerk draw any warrant or warrant check which shall call for the payment of funds not represented by cash in the City Treasury nor for which the total amount shall be in excess of the amount authorized for the expenses of any such fund by the annual City budget. 
(Prior Code, § 1-209; Ord. No. 1645 , § 11, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 2-119. - Records appointments; file oaths; bonds. 
    The City Clerk shall record every appointment of office and the date thereof. He/she shall also record the appointment of boards, commissions and committees which the Mayor, the City Council or the Governing Body are authorized to appoint. He/she shall receive, file and preserve all oaths of office, other oaths required and bonds of the City officers required to be given by law or ordinance. He/she shall preserve the same in a suitable file and keep the Governing Body fully advised thereon. 
(Prior Code, § 1-210; Ord. No. 1645 , § 13, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 2-120. - Bond record. 
    The City Clerk or his/her designee shall keep a fully accurate account of all bonds issued by the City by date, number, amount thereof, rate of interest, number of each coupon, amount of each, where payable, date of maturity, and when canceled upon the return of same to the City. 
(Prior Code, § 1-211; Ord. No. 1645 , § 15, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 2-121. - Special assessments. 
    The City Clerk or his/her designee shall keep a record of all special assessments whenever the same shall have been made and he/she shall certify said assessments to the County Clerk in the manner provided by law. 
(Prior Code, § 1-212; Ord. No. 1645 , § 17, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 2-122. - Settlement with Treasurer. 
    The City Clerk shall enter in a suitable record under appropriate heading the amounts received by the City Treasurer, as shown by his receipt. The amounts so received, said records and vouchers shall be for reference in the settlements between the City Treasurer and the County Treasurer. 
(Prior Code, § 1-213; Ord. No. 1645 , § 19, 2-13-2017) 
Sec. 2-123. - Federal income tax withholding; other withholding. 
    The City Clerk is hereby designated as the withholding agent of the City for the purposes of the Federal income tax, and the City Clerk shall perform the duties required of withholding agents by the act or any other act requiring withholding from the compensation of any City officer or employee. 
(Prior Code, § 1-214; Ord. No. 1645 , § 20, 2-13-2017) 
Secs. 2-124-2-144. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY TREASURER 

Sec. 2-145. - Receives money belonging to City; taxes. 
    The City Treasurer shall receive from the County Treasurer all monies and evidences of indebtedness collected for and payable to the City as provided by law. He shall keep proper record by funds of all monies received from any source as provided by law and keep a full and accurate record of all monies received and disbursed by him in behalf of the City specifying the time of receipt or disbursement, and from whom received and to whom disbursed on account. He shall publish or cause to be published a quarterly financial statement of the City in the manner and style provided by law. 
(Prior Code, § 1-215) 
Sec. 2-146. - Deposits. 
    The City Treasurer shall deposit all public monies coming into his hands in his official capacity or responsibility in any financial institution authorized by existing State statutes as designated from time to time by the City Council and after the depository bank shall have given a bond as provided by law in those instances where a depository of public monies must give security. 
(Prior Code, § 1-216) 
Sec. 2-147. - Disbursements. 
    The City Treasurer shall pay out of the funds of the City upon warrant checks properly signed by the Mayor and attested by the City Clerk and countersigned by him. He shall not knowingly pay any order, warrant or warrant check or other evidence of indebtedness out of the treasury of the City in excess of the funds actually on hand in the treasury at the time for such purpose. No warrant, warrant check or certificate of indebtedness shall be registered or paid by him for any other purpose than for that for which the tax levy is made (where one is made) and no part of any fund shall be diverted in any manner to the payment of claims against the City other than for the purpose which any such fund shall have been created. 
(Prior Code, § 1-217) 
Secs. 2-148-2-177. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS 

Sec. 2-178. - Employee handbook. 
    Employee benefits shall be provided for in the employee handbook as adopted by the City Council. 
Secs. 2-179-2-209. - Reserved.

Secs. 2-210-2-223. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Powers of police, K.S.A. 12-4212, 12-4111, 22-4191. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 2-228. - Composition. 
    The Police Department of the City shall consist of the Chief of Police and such number of regular police officers and civilian staff as shall be approved by the Police Committee and provided for in the City budget. 
(Prior Code, § 9-101; Ord. No. 1685 , § 1, 1-30-2019) 
Sec. 2-229. - Duties of the Chief of Police. 
    The Chief of Police shall have supervisory responsibility for the operation of the Department including the power to make such rules and regulations as may be necessary for the proper and efficient conduct of law enforcement within the City. The Chief of Police shall perform such duties and functions as are assigned elsewhere in the Code. 
(Prior Code, § 9-103; Ord. No. 1685 , § 3, 1-30-2019) 
Secs. 2-230-2-251. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Lost and Unclaimed Property 

Sec. 2-252. - Lost and unclaimed property. 
    All personal property of any nature which shall remain unclaimed in the possession of the Police Department for a period of six (6) months, except weapons confiscated pursuant to K.S.A. 21-6307, is hereby determined to be lost and unclaimed property, provided that the City has no knowledge or information as to the identity of the rightful owner, or having received at least thirty (30) days' written notice, the rightful owner neglects and fails to claim same from the City. 
(Prior Code, § 9-201; Ord. No. 725; Ord. No. 1476) 
Sec. 2-253. - Rights of finder. 
    A finder of lost and unclaimed property that has delivered possession thereof to the City shall be notified by the Police Department that the property is lost and unclaimed and that said finder is entitled to possession thereof. Upon giving of proper receipt, the finder is entitled to be given possession of such lost and unclaimed property. Nothing in this subdivision shall imply that said finder is bound to accept possession of such lost and unclaimed property if he declines to do so. 
(Prior Code, § 9-202; Ord. No. 725) 
Sec. 2-254. - Disposal of lost and unclaimed property. 
    The Police Department may dispose of all lost and unclaimed property, subject to the rights of any finder as provided in this subdivision, by selling same at public auction after first advertising the date and location of such public auction as the City Council may direct. If there is no bid on any item of lost or unclaimed property at the public auction, this shall constitute conclusive evidence that the property is of no value, and the City may dispose of same by donating said property to a recognized public charity. If the City Council determines that the value of the unclaimed property does not justify the expense of a public auction, it may direct donation of said property to a recognized public charity. 
(Prior Code, § 9-203; Ord. No. 725; Ord. No. 1065) 
Sec. 2-255. - Proceeds. 
    All proceeds received from the sale of lost and unclaimed property, other than firearms, shall be placed in the general fund. 
(Prior Code, § 9-204; Ord. No. 72) 
Sec. 2-256. - Confiscated property. 
    All property confiscated by the Police Department for which the rightful owner cannot be found within six (6) months, except weapons confiscated pursuant to K.S.A. 21-6307, is included within the above definition of unclaimed property. However, nothing in this subdivision shall be construed to give the perpetrator of a crime the status of "finder." 
(Prior Code, § 9-205; Ord. No. 725; Ord. No. 1476) 
Sec. 2-257. - Disposition of weapons. 
(a)  Any stolen weapon that has been seized and detained, when no longer needed for evidentiary purposes, shall be returned to the person entitled to possession, if known. All other weapons confiscated pursuant to K.S.A. 21-6307 or otherwise held by the Police Department, when no longer needed for evidentiary purposes, shall, in the discretion of the Chief of Police, be: 
(1)  Destroyed; 
(2)  Forfeited to the Police Department for its use, for sale to a properly licensed Federal firearms dealer, for trading to a properly licensed Federal firearms dealer for other new or used firearms or accessories for use, or for trading to another law enforcement agency for that agency's use; or 
(3)  Forfeited to the State Bureau of Investigation for law enforcement, testing, comparison or destruction by the State Bureau of Investigation Forensic Laboratory. 
(b)  If weapons are sold as authorized by Subsection (a)(2) of this section, the proceeds of the sales shall be credited to the asset seizure and forfeiture fund of the seizing agency. 
(Prior Code, § 9-206; Ord. No. 1476) 
Secs. 2-258-2-277. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Canine Corps 

Sec. 2-278. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions defined in this subdivision shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Prior Code, § 9-304; Ord. No. 752) 
Sec. 2-279. - Canine Corps. 
    Any dog used, whether owned, leased, rented or borrowed for the purpose of performing duties with the Police Department, shall be commissioned as a member of the Canine Corps and shall perform such duties as may be designated by the Chief of Police or the officer in charge of such unit and who has been designated the responsibility for handling and supervision of such animal. 
(Prior Code, § 9-301; Ord. No. 752) 
Sec. 2-280. - Abuse prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to strike, hit, beat, abuse, tease, harass, pet or assault any dog being used for the purpose of performing the duties of a police dog regardless of whether the dog is on duty or off duty. 
(Prior Code, § 9-302; Ord. No. 752) 
Sec. 2-281. - Interference prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with a dog being used by the Police Department or attempt to interfere with the handler of said dog in such a manner as to inhibit, restrict or deprive said handler of his control of the dog. 
(Prior Code, § 9-303; Ord. No. 752) 
Secs. 2-282-2-289. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - MUNICIPAL COURT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Kansas Code of Procedure for Municipal Courts, K.S.A. 12-4101 et seq.; jurisdiction of Municipal Courts, K.S.A. 12-4103; judge generally, K.S.A. 12-4105; powers and duties of judge, K.S.A. 12-4106; docket, K.S.A. 12-4106; vacancy in office of municipal judge and municipal judge pro temp, K.S.A. 12-4107; bond of Clerk of Municipal Court, K.S.A. 12-4108; supplies, etc., for Municipal Court, K.S.A. 12-4109; City Attorney to prosecute in Municipal Court, K.S.A. 12-4110; powers of law enforcement officers, K.S.A. 12-4111; sentencing, K.S.A. 12-4509. 

Sec. 2-311. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accused person means a person, corporation or other legal entity accused by a complaint of the violation of a City ordinance. 
    Appearance bond means an undertaking, with or without security, entered into by a person in custody by which he binds himself to comply with such conditions as are set forth thereon. 
    Arraignment means the formal act of calling the person accused of violating an ordinance before the Municipal Court to inform him of the offense with which he is charged, to ask him whether he is guilty or not guilty, and, if guilty, to impose sentence. 
    Arrest means the taking of a person into custody in order that he may be forthcoming to answer for the violation of an ordinance. The giving of a notice to appear is not an arrest. 
    Bail means the security given for the purpose of insuring compliance with the terms of an appearance bond. 
    City Attorney means any attorney who represents the City in the prosecution of an accused person for the violation of a City ordinance. 
    Complaint means a sworn written statement of the essential facts constituting a violation of an ordinance. 
    Custody means the restraint of a person pursuant to an arrest. 
    Detention means the temporary restraint of a person by a law enforcement officer. 
    Law enforcement officer means any person who by virtue of his office or public employment is vested by law with a duty to maintain public order and to make arrests for violation of the State laws or ordinances of any municipality thereof. 
    Notice to appear means a written notice to a person accused by complaint of having violated a City ordinance to appear at a stated time and place to answer to the charge of the complaint. 
    Subpoena means a process issued by the Court to cause a witness to appear and give testimony at a time and place therein specified. 
    Warrant means a written order made by a Municipal Judge directed to any law enforcement officer commanding such officer to arrest the person named or described thereon (K.S.A. 12-4113). 
(Prior Code, § 8-112) 
Sec. 2-312. - Statutes incorporated by reference. 
    The "Kansas Code of Procedure for Municipal Courts," being K.S.A. ch. 12, arts. 41 to 47, inclusive, (K.S.A. 12-4101 et seq.), is by reference incorporated in this article and together with the other provisions of this article shall be known as "Fairway Municipal Court Code." 
(Prior Code, § 8-113; Ord. No. 1464) 
Sec. 2-313. - Schedule of costs and fees. 
(a)  There is hereby established the following fee schedule for the administration of justice in the Municipal Court of the City: 
(1)  Costs may be assessed against each accused person in any case in which the accused person has failed to appear in court or to satisfy the financial or other requirements of the Court's order. These costs shall be in addition to the reinstatement fee collected by the Court pursuant to K.S.A. 8-2110(c) and amendments thereto. The court may assess these costs for each case in which the person failed to appear or to make satisfaction regardless of the disposition of the case for which the complaint was originally issued; 
(2)  If, upon application of a defendant, the Municipal Court Judge appoints counsel for the defendant, a fee shall be assessed against the defendant equal to the actual cost of such defense or such lesser amount as the Court determines, based upon the evidence before it, that the defendant is financially able to pay; provided that, if it is later found that the defendant intentionally provided untrue information in or in support of the application for a appointment of counsel, said fee shall be increased to the actual cost of defense regardless of the outcome of the case; 
(3)  A fee in the amount established by ordinance shall be assessed against a defendant upon conviction or diversion in each case in which said defendant is incarcerated pursuant to an order of the Municipal Court Judge; 
(4)  A fingerprinting fee in the amount established by ordinance shall be assessed against a defendant in each case in which the defendant has been convicted of violating municipal ordinance provisions that prohibit conduct comparable to a Class A or B misdemeanor or assault as defined in K.S.A. 21-3408 and amendments thereto under the State Criminal Statutes; 
(5)  Costs and fees shall be assessed as may be required by State statutes; 
(6)  Additional court costs and fees may be assessed by the Municipal Court for service of process, for transcripts and depositions, and for expenses incurred in serving a warrant. 
(b)  These costs and fees shall be assessed as part of the judgment and shall be collected by the Municipal Court Clerk/Municipal Court Administrator. 
(c)  The costs and fees assessed pursuant to this section shall be in addition to the fine imposed. 
(Prior Code, § 8-111; Ord. No. 1464) 
Sec. 2-314. - Contempt of court. 
    Contempts of court are divided into two (2) classes, direct and indirect, and shall be proceeded against only as prescribed in this section. 
(1)  Generally. Contempts committed during the sitting of the Court or of a Judge at chambers, in its or his presence, are direct contempts. All others are indirect contempts. 
(2)  Direct contempts . A direct contempt may be punished summarily, without written accusation against the person arraigned, but if the Court for Judge in chambers shall adjudge guilty thereof, a judgment shall be entered of record, in which shall be specified the conduct constituting such contempt, with a statement of whatever defense or extenuation of the excused offered thereto, and the sentence of the Court thereon. 
(3)  Indirect contempts. 
a.  Upon the return of an officer on process or an affidavit duly filed showing any person guilty of indirect contempt, lawful process may issue, and such person be arrested and brought before the Court or Judge in chambers; and thereupon a written accusation setting forth succinctly and clearly the facts alleged to constitute such contempt shall be filed, and the accused required to answer the same, by an order which shall fix the time therefore and also the time and place for hearing the matter; and the Court or Judge in chambers shall, on proper showing, extend the time so as to give the accused a reasonable opportunity to purge himself of such contempt. 
b.  After the answer of the accused, or if he refuses or fails to answer, the Court or Judge may proceed at the time so fixed to hear and determine such accusation upon such testimony as shall be produced. If the accused answers, the trial shall proceed upon testimony produced as in criminal cases, and the accused shall be entitled to be confronted with the witnesses against him; but such trial shall be by the Court or Judge. If the accused is found guilty, judgment shall be entered accordingly, prescribing the punishment. 
(4)  Penalty . Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment of not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Prior Code, § 8-114; Ord. No. 700) 
Sec. 2-315. - Failure to appear. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person to fail to appear before the Municipal Court of the City for trial or other proceedings prior to and/or after a conviction of a public offense by a person who has been released on an appearance bond by said Court; said offense will be known as failure to appear. 
(1)  Failure to appear. Incurring forfeiture of an appearance bond and failing to surrender oneself within thirty (30) days following the date of such forfeiture by one who is charged with a public offense, who has been released on bond for appearance before the Municipal Court of the City for trial or other proceedings prior to conviction, or who incurs a forfeiture of an appearance bond and fails to surrender oneself within thirty (30) days after one's conviction of a public offense has become final. 
(2)  Release on bond. Any person, who is released upon his own recognizance, without surety, who fails to appear in response to a summons or traffic citation, or who fails to appear on his promise to appear, is a person released on bond for appearance within the meaning of this section. 
(3)  Penalty . Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Prior Code, § 8-115; Ord. No. 722) 
Sec. 2-316. - Clerk of the Municipal Court. 
    The Clerk of the Municipal Court shall make reports to the Judicial Administrator and furnish the information when requested by him or a Departmental Justice on such forms furnished by the Judicial Administrator and approved by the Supreme Court. 
(Prior Code, § 8-106) 
State Law reference- Duties of clerk of court, K.S.A. 12-4108. 
Secs. 2-317-2-335. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FINANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-336. - Fees and charges. 
    Whenever in this Code it is provided that fees or charges are as established or provided by resolution, or by ordinance or by a fee schedule, or when language substantially similar to foregoing is used in this Code, such language shall mean that the fees or charges may be established by resolution, ordinance or any other method not prohibited by law. 
Secs. 2-337-2-360. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INVESTMENT OF IDLE FUNDS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Investment of idle funds, K.S.A. 12-1675. 

Sec. 2-361. - Authority to invest. 
    Temporarily idle monies not currently needed may be invested in accordance with the procedure provided for in K.S.A. 12-1675, which is incorporated by reference in this division as if set out in full. 
(Prior Code, § 1-501) 
Sec. 2-362. - Procedure and restrictions. 
    The City Treasurer shall periodically report to the Governing Body as to the amount of monies available for investment and the period of time such amounts will be available for investment, and shall submit such recommendations as deemed necessary for the efficient and safe management of the City finances. The recommendations of the City Treasurer shall provide for an investment program which shall so limit the amounts invested and schedule the maturities of investments so that the City will at all times have sufficient monies available on demand deposit to ensure prompt payment of all City obligations. 
(Prior Code, § 1-502; Ord. No. 373, § 2) 
Sec. 2-363. - Sale or transfer. 
    If, in order to maintain sufficient monies on demand deposit in any fund, as provided in Section 2-362, it becomes necessary to transfer or sell any securities of such funds, the City Clerk and City Treasurer may transfer said securities to any other fund in which there are temporarily idle monies, or shall sell any such securities and for such purpose they shall have authority to make any necessary written directions, endorsements or assignments for and on behalf of the City. Any such transfers or sales shall be reported in writing to the Governing Body at the next regular meeting of the City Council. 
(Prior Code, § 1-503; Ord. No. 373, § 5) 
Sec. 2-364. - Earnings and records. 
    The interest or other earnings from investments made pursuant to this division shall be credited pro rata to the fund from which the investments were made and shall be used, insofar as possible, to relieve the ad valorem tax levies of the City. The City Treasurer shall maintain a complete and detailed record at all times of all investments made pursuant to this division. 
(Prior Code, § 1-504; Ord. No. 373, § 5) 
Secs. 2-365-2-386. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LIENS ON PROPERTY DAMAGE INSURANCE PROCEEDS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal claims on fire insurance police proceeds, K.S.A. 12-3901 et seq. 

Sec. 2-387. - Insurance proceeds. 
    If fire, explosion or windstorm causes damage to a structure that is covered by fire, explosion or windstorm insurance and the covered claim payment is in excess of seventy-five percent (75%) of the face value of the policy covering the structure, then the insurance provider shall be required to pay to the City fifteen percent (15%) of the claim payment. The insurer shall first pay all amounts due to the holder of a first real estate mortgage against the structure pursuant to the terms of the policy and endorsements thereto and then shall withhold from the covered claim payment the sums required to be paid to the City. Such payments shall be made to the City on or before the date any monies are released by the insurer to any party or within thirty (30) days of the incident resulting in the claim, whichever is earlier in time; the payment shall be made by check or money order made payable to the City, no post-dating of the check will be allowed, and sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the City Clerk 4210 Shawnee Mission Parkway, Suite 100, Fairway, Kansas 66205, along with a statement explaining the reason for payment and giving the address of the property involved. All such funds received by the City Clerk shall be placed in an interest-bearing account of the City. 
(Prior Code, § 6-601) 
Sec. 2-388. - Proof of repairing or rebuilding. 
    In lieu of the payment of proceeds required in Section 2-387, the insured may present satisfactory proof to the City Building Inspector that the insured has or will remove debris and repair, rebuild or otherwise make the premises safe and secure. Upon presentation of such sufficient evidence, the City Building Inspector along with the City Clerk shall certify that adequate proof of repairing or rebuilding has been given and that the payment of insurance proceeds to the City shall not be paid, subject to any lien created by the City should the insured fail to rebuild, repair or secure the property as presented. The insured shall be responsible for presenting such certificate to the insurer. The insured, in seeking such certificate, shall present a timetable showing when repairs or rebuilding will be completed; render architectural or engineer plans subject to approval by the City Building Inspector, showing the method, manner and materials to be used in repairing or rebuilding, and any other evidence deemed necessary by the City Building Inspector to demonstrate that the repairs or rebuilding will be completed in a timely and lawful manner. Failure of the insured to comply with the certificate shall result in institution of proceedings for abatement. 
(Prior Code, § 6-602) 
Sec. 2-389. - Failure to pay insurance proceeds or to obtain a certificate. 
    It is unlawful for any person, corporation, partnership, agency or entity to fail to provide the payment of insurance proceeds as required by this division, unless a certificate in lieu of payment proceeds has been obtained through the City. 
(Prior Code, § 6-604; Ord. No. 1044) 
Secs. 2-390-2-406. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PUBLIC RECORDS ACCESS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Open Records Act, K.S.A. 45-215 et seq. 

Sec. 2-407. - Statement of purpose; review. 
    It is the purpose of this article to establish reasonable fees and charges for the provisions of access to or copies of open public records in the possession of the City to avoid the necessity of using general public funds of the City to subsidize special services and benefits to a record requestor. The Official Record Custodian shall periodically recommend to the Governing Body such changes in this article as may be necessary to secure this purpose. 
(Prior Code, § 1-601; Ord. No. 810) 
Sec. 2-408. - Inspection fee. 
    Inspection fees for open public records shall be as follows: 
(1)  Where a request has been made for inspection of any open public record which is readily available to the Record Custodian, there shall be no inspection fee charged to the requestor. 
(2)  In all cases not covered by Subsection (1) of this section, a record inspection fee shall be charged at the rate established by ordinance. 
(Prior Code, § 1-602; Ord. No. 810) 
State Law reference- Inspection fees, K.S.A. 45-218. 
Sec. 2-409. - Copying fee. 
    The fee for photocopying open public records shall be as follows: 
(1)  In the amount established by ordinance, for such fee to cover the costs of labor, materials and equipment. 
(2)  The fees provided in this section shall not apply to photocopying ordinances to permit applications, in that such fees are included in the permit fee. 
(3)  For photocopying any public record which cannot be reproduced by the City's photocopying equipment, the requestor shall be charged the actual cost to the City, including staff time, in reproducing such records. 
(Prior Code, § 1-603; Ord. No. 810; Ord. No. 1085) 
State Law reference- Fees for copies of records, K.S.A. 45-219. 
Sec. 2-410. - Prepayment of fees. 
    Prepayment of fees may be required as follows: 
(1)  A Record Custodian may demand prepayment of the fees established by ordinance whenever he believes this to be in the best interest of the City. The prepayment amount shall be an estimate of the inspection and/or copying charges accrued in fulfilling the record request. Any overage or underage in the prepayment shall be settled prior to inspection of the requested record or delivery of the requested copies.
