[A] 103.2 Appointment. 
The fire code official shall be the fire chief of the Consolidated Fire District No. 2 of Johnson County, Kansas. 
(3)  Section [A] 103.3 of the International Fire Code, 2012 Edition, Deputies, is hereby amended to read as follows: 
[A] 103.3 Deputies. 
As prescribed in Section 5-2 of the Code of the City of Fairway, Kansas, the fire code official shall have the authority to appoint a deputy fire code official, other related technical officers, inspectors and other employees. Additional enforcement authority is granted as provided in said Section 5-2. 
(4)  Section [A] 108.1 of the International Fire Code, 2012 Edition, board of appeals established, is hereby amended to read as follows: 
[A] 108.1 Board of appeals established. 
In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the fire code official relative to the application and interpretation of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a board of appeals. 
(5)  Section [A] 108.3 of the International Fire Code, 2012 Edition, is hereby omitted in full. 
(Prior Code, § 5-105; Ord. No. 946; Ord. No. 1271; Ord. No. 1607 , § 1, 12-14-2015) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference authorized, K.S.A. 12-3009 et seq., 12-3301 et seq. 
Sec. 5-2. - Administration and enforcement. 
    The Fire Chief of the Northeast Johnson County Consolidated Fire District No. 2 Fire Department shall be responsible for the enforcement of the fire code adopted by the City. Said Fire Chief may detail qualified members or qualified agents of said Fire Department as inspectors as shall be necessary from time to time. The appropriate City officers are empowered to issue and serve complaints upon advice of the Fire Department. 
(1)  The Chief of Police shall, in accordance with provisions of City ordinances and State laws, take all prudent measures to prevent all fires on any premises or place within the City limits. The Chief of Police, or a member of the Police Department under his direction may, whenever he has reasons to believe that the safety of persons or property from the hazards of the fire demand and as often as he may deem proper, enter upon any premises, yard, or buildings within the City to examine and inspect the same. 
(2)  The Chief of Police is authorized to direct or cause the owner or tenant of any of the aforesaid building, premises or places to make such alterations in the kind, management or keeping of such buildings or places and the storage, use or handling of such materials as will remove or lessen the likelihood of fire and may order the removal of all materials kept, stored, handled or used in violation of ordinance or law. 
(Prior Code, §§ 5-101, 5-106; Ord. No. 946; Ord. No. 1271) 
Sec. 5-3. - Fire hazards. 
    Any situation, condition, activity, object or substance conducive to the outbreak or spreading of fire in the City is declared to be a fire hazard and it shall be unlawful for any person to cause or create any such condition or situation within the City or to permit or suffer to be on any premises under his or their control any activity, object or substance conducive to or likely to cause the outbreak of fire except as may otherwise be provided by ordinance or State laws. 
(Prior Code, § 5-102; Ord. No. 453) 
Sec. 5-4. - Burning is prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or business entity to dispose of any garbage or trash by burning unless by special permission as prescribed by Section 5-5; provided that this restriction shall not be construed to prohibit any such disposal in an approved type incinerator enclosed within a building that meets any and all applicable State or Federal requirements. 
(Prior Code, § 5-103; Ord. No. 543, § 1; Ord. No. 1271) 
Sec. 5-5. - Special permission. 
    Upon written request to the City Clerk naming the material, time, location and need to burn material of any kind, the City Council may grant special permission to burn where the conditions so warrant. 
(Prior Code, § 5-104; Ord. No. 543, § 2) 
Sec. 5-6. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Prior Code, § 5-107; Ord. No. 611) 
Secs. 5-7-5-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS AND L-P GASES 

Sec. 5-31. - Aboveground tanks prohibited. 
    No person shall hereafter erect or place any aboveground tanks for the storage of flammable liquids within the City. 
(Prior Code, § 5-201; Ord. No. 453) 
Sec. 5-32. - Bulk oil stations, service stations. 
    The storage, handling and use of flammable liquids, and the design, construction and installation of containers and equipment for the storage and handling of flammable liquids, at bulk oil stations and service stations within the City shall be in compliance with the Rules and Regulations of the State Fire Marshal's Department, Article 7, and amendments thereto, as filed with the Revisor of Statutes (effective January 1, 1972), and the Rules and Regulations are hereby incorporated by reference as provided by law and made a part of this article as if the same had been set out in full in this article (K.S.A. 12-3009 to 12-3012). 
(Prior Code, § 5-202) 
Sec. 5-33. - L-P gases. 
    The design, construction and installation of containers and equipment for the storage and handling of liquefied petroleum gases within the City shall be governed by and in compliance with the Rules and Regulations Relating to the Liquefied Petroleum Gas Industry of the State of Kansas, Article 8, as promulgated by the State Fire Marshal's Department as filed with the Revisor of Statutes (effective January 1, 1973) and the Rules and Regulations are hereby incorporated by reference and shall be as much as part of this article as if the same had been set out in full in this article (K.S.A. 12-3009 to 12-3012). 
(Prior Code, § 5-203) 
Sec. 5-34. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article or the Rules and Regulations incorporated in this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Prior Code, § 5-204) 
Secs. 5-35-5-56. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIREWORKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Fireworks regulations authorized, K.S.A. 31-134. 

Sec. 5-57. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fire Official means the Chief of Police, or his designated representative. 
    Fireworks means any combustible or explosive composition, or any substance or combination of substances or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or an audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include toy pistols, toy cannons, toy canes or toy guns in which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require rockets underneath to propel the same, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, Daygo bombs, sparklers, or other devices of like construction, and any devices containing any explosive or flammable compound, or any tablets or other device containing any explosive substance. The term "fireworks" does not include any toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which are used paper caps which contain an average of twenty-five hundredths (0.25) or less of a grain of explosive content per cap, nor any toy pistol paper caps manufactured as provided in this article, the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times. Each package containing toy paper caps offered for retail sale shall be labeled to indicate the maximum explosive content per cap. 
(Prior Code, § 5-301; Ord. No. 635) 
Sec. 5-58. - Fireworks prohibited; exceptions. 
    No person shall store, offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at retail, use, explode or discharge any fireworks except for supervised public exhibitions or displays; provided, however, that such public exhibitions or displays shall be conducted only in accordance with any rules and regulations issued by the Fire Official; provided, further, however, that the provisions and prohibitions of this section shall not be construed to prohibit the proper and lawful storage of fireworks, by an actual wholesaler, for sale outside the City limits. 
(Prior Code, § 5-302; Ord. No. 635) 
Sec. 5-59. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Prior Code, § 5-303; Ord. No. 635)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 6-1-6-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Nuisance ordinances authorized, K.S.A. 12-1617g; nuisance abatement, K.S.A. 12-1617e; weed removal, K.S.A. 12-1617f. 

Sec. 6-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nuisance means an annoyance, and any use of property which endangers the life or health, violates the laws of decency, unreasonably pollutes the air with foul noxious odors or smoke, or obstructs the reasonable and comfortable use and enjoyment of the property of another or of the public. 
(Prior Code, § 6-201; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1350) 
Sec. 6-20. - General nuisances. 
    In addition to those nuisances otherwise specifically prohibited by ordinance, it shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit to exist any nuisance. 
(Prior Code, § 6-202; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1350) 
Sec. 6-21. - Deposit of certain substances endangering health. 
    No person shall dispose of any substance or material which is or may be a menace to public health or welfare or a danger to the health or welfare of the inhabitants of the City, or of any neighborhood, family or resident thereof. 
(Prior Code, § 6-204; Ord. No. 611) 
Sec. 6-22. - Inoperative vehicles and/or equipment. 
(a)  Generally. The City Council finds that junked, wrecked, dismantled, inoperative or abandoned vehicles and/or equipment affect the health, safety and general welfare of citizens of the City in that they: 
(1)  Serve as a breeding ground for flies, mosquitoes, rats and other insects and rodents; 
(2)  Are a danger to persons, particularly children, because of broken glass, sharp metal protrusions, insecure mounting on blocks, jacks or other supports; 
(3)  Are a ready source of fire and explosion; 
(4)  Encourage pilfering and theft; 
(5)  Constitute a blighting influence upon the area in which they are located; 
(6)  Constitute a fire hazard because they frequently block access for fire equipment to adjacent buildings and structures. 
(b)  Definitions . The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Inoperable means a condition of being junked, wrecked, wholly or partially dismantled, discarded, abandoned or unable to perform the function or purpose for which it was originally constructed. 
    Motor vehicle means, without limitation, any vehicle or equipment which as originally built contained an engine, regardless of whether it contains an engine at any other time. 
    Vehicle and/or equipment includes, without limitation, any automobile, van, recreational vehicle, truck, tractor, boat, trailer or motorcycle. 
(c)  Nuisances unlawful; defined; exceptions . It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or permit any motor vehicle nuisance within the City. 
(1)  A motor vehicle nuisance is any motor vehicle which is not currently registered or tagged pursuant to K.S.A. 8-126 to 8-149 inclusive, as amended; or parked in violation of a City ordinance; or incapable of moving under its own power; or in a junked, wrecked or inoperable condition. Any one (1) of the following conditions shall raise the presumption that a motor vehicle is junked, wrecked or inoperable: 
a.  Absence of a current registration plate upon the vehicle; 
b.  Placement of the vehicle or parts thereof upon jacks, blocks or other supports; 
c.  Absence of one or more parts of the vehicle necessary for the lawful operation of the vehicle upon a street or highway. 
(2)  The provisions of this Subsection (c) shall not apply to: 
a.  Any motor vehicle which is enclosed in a garage or other building; 
b.  To the parking or storage of a vehicle inoperable for a period of thirty (30) consecutive days or less; or 
c.  To any person conducting a business enterprise in compliance with existing zoning regulations or who places such vehicles behind screening of sufficient size, strength and density to screen such vehicles from the view of the public and to prohibit ready access to stored vehicles by children. However, nothing in this subsection shall be construed to authorize the maintenance of a public nuisance. 
(d)  Complaints, inquiry and inspection . 
(1)  Any police officer or Codes Administrator shall make inquiry and inspection of premises: 
a.  Upon receiving a complaint or complaints in writing signed by two (2) or more persons stating that a nuisance exists and describing the same and where located; or 
b.  When informed that a nuisance may exist by the Chief of Police or by the Board of Health or Fire Chief. 
(2)  The police officer or Codes Administrator may make such inquiry and inspection when he observes conditions which appear to constitute a nuisance. 
(3)  Upon making an inquiry and inspection, the police officer shall make a written report of findings. 
(e)  Right of entry . It shall be a violation of this section to deny any police officer the right of access and entry upon private property at any reasonable time for purpose of making inquiry and inspection to determine if a nuisance exists. 
(f)  Notice . Any person, corporation, partnership or association found by a police officer to be in violation of this section shall be served a notice of such violation. The notice shall be served by registered mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested; provided that if the owner or his agent in charge of the property is a resident of the County, the notice shall be personally served by a law enforcement officer. 
(g)  Same; contents . The notice shall state the conditions which are in violation of this section. The notice shall also inform the person, corporation, partnership or association that: 
(1)  He shall have ten (10) days from date of serving the notice to abate the conditions in violation of this article; or 
(2)  He shall have ten (10) days from date of serving the notice to request a hearing before the Governing Body, as provided in Subsection (j) of this section; 
(3)  Failure to abate the conditions or to request a hearing within the time allowed may result in prosecution as provided in this section and/or abatement of the conditions by the City as provided in this section. 
(h)  Failure to comply . Should the person, corporation, partnership or association fail to comply with the notice to abate the nuisance or request a hearing, the police officer may file a complaint in the Municipal Court of the City against such person, corporation, partnership or association. 
(i)  Abatement . In addition to, or as an alternative to prosecution as provided in this section, the police officer may seek to remedy violations of this section in the following manner. If a person to whom notice has been sent pursuant to this section has neither alleviated the conditions causing the alleged violation nor requested a hearing before the City Council within the time periods allowed in this section, the police officer may present a resolution to the Governing Body for adoption authorizing the police officer or other agents of the City to abate the conditions causing the violation at the end of ten (10) days after passage of the resolution. The resolution shall further provide that the costs incurred by the City shall be charged against the lot or parcel of ground on which the nuisance was located as provided in this section. A copy of the resolution shall be served upon the person in violation in one (1) of the following ways: 
(1)  Personal service upon the person in violation; 
(2)  Service by registered mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested; or 
(3)  In the event the whereabouts of such person is unknown and same cannot be ascertained in the exercise of reasonable diligence, an affidavit to that effect shall be made by the police officer and filed with the City Clerk, and the serving of the resolution shall be made by publishing the same once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the official City newspaper and by posting a copy of the resolution on the premises where such condition exists. 
(j)  Hearing . If a hearing is requested within the ten (10) day period as provided in this section, such request shall be made in writing to the City Council. Failure to make a timely request for a hearing shall constitute a waiver of the person's right to contest the findings of the police officer before the City Council. The hearing shall be held by the City Council as soon as possible after the filing of the request therefor, and the person shall be advised by the City of the time and place of the hearing at least five (5) days in advance thereof. At any such hearing, the person may be represented by counsel, and the person in the City may introduce such witnesses and evidence as is deemed necessary and proper by the City Council. The hearing need not be conducted according to the formal rules of evidence. Upon conclusion of the hearing, the City Council shall record its determination of the matter by means of adopting a resolution and serving the resolution upon the person in the manner provided in this section. 
(k)  Costs assessed . If the City abates the nuisance pursuant to the provisions of this section, the cost of abatement shall be charged against the lot or parcel of ground on which the nuisance was located. The City Clerk shall, at the time of certifying other taxes to the County Clerk, certify the costs as provided in this section. The County Clerk shall extend the same on the tax roll and it shall be collected by the County Treasurer and paid to the City as other City taxes are collected and paid. 
(Prior Code, § 6-205; Ord. No. 931) 
Sec. 6-23. - Selling motor vehicles; premises, residential or nonbusiness. 
    No person shall offer, show or display for sale a motor vehicle on property zoned business. No person shall offer, show or display for sale a motor vehicle on property zoned residential unless the offer, showing or display is occasional. The term "occasional" is defined as an offer, showing or display of a motor vehicle from residential property of not more than two (2) motor vehicles in any twelve (12) month period and not more than one (1) motor vehicle at any one (1) time. 
(Prior Code, § 6-206; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 858) 
Sec. 6-24. - Penalty. 
    Any person, corporation, partnership or association violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day on which violation occurs or continues after notice has been served shall constitute an additional or separate offense. 
Secs. 6-25-6-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 6-52. - Adoption of property maintenance code. 
    There is hereby incorporated by reference the International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC), Edition 2000, prepared and published by the International Code Council, Inc.; provided certain parts or portions thereof shall be omitted, amended, replaced or supplemented as specified by Sections 6-53 to 6-56. No fewer than three (3) copies of this code shall be marked or stamped "Official copy as incorporated by Ordinance No. 1304," and these copies shall be filed with the City Clerk to be open for inspection and available to the public at all reasonable business hours, provided that these official copies may not be removed from City Hall. A copy of Ordinance No. 1304 shall be attached to all official copies of this Code. All City officials requiring the use of this code shall be supplied, at the expense of the City, the number of official copies of this code as may be deemed expedient by the City Council. Should any provision of the property maintenance code conflict with any other provision of this Code or the zoning ordinance, then the more restrictive of the two (2) provisions shall take precedence. 
(Prior Code, § 6-901) 
Sec. 6-53. - Amendment to Chapter 1 of the property maintenance code as published. 
    The following sections of Chapter 1 of the International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC), Edition 2000, shall be omitted, amended, replaced or supplemented as follows: 
(1)  Section 101.1 regarding title. Insert: "the City of Fairway." 
(2)  Section 102.3 regarding application of other codes. Replace with: 
102.3 Application of other codes . Repairs, additions or alterations to a structure, or changes of occupancy, shall be done in accordance with the procedures and provisions of the City of Fairway's approved building code, energy conservation code, residential code, plumbing code, mechanical code, fuel gas code, electrical code, City Code, zoning ordinance or other applicable regulations. 
(3)  Section 103.6 regarding fees. Replace with: 
103.6 Fees. The fees for activities and services performed by the department in carrying out its responsibilities under this code shall be as indicated in the fee schedule separately approved by the City Council, which, for the purposes of this section, shall be considered incorporated in this section by reference. 
(4)  Section 106.4 regarding violation penalties. Replace with: 
106.4 Violations; Repeat Offenders; Chronic Offenders; penalties. Any person who shall violate a provision of this code, or fail to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof, shall be prosecuted in the Municipal Court of the City. Any such person found guilty of violating these provisions shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
106.4.1 Repeat Violation; Process. If a repeat violation is found, the Code Official shall provide a notice of repeat violation to the repeat offender. The Code Official, however, is not required to give the repeat offender reasonable time to correct the violation, because the repeat offender, by the repeated violations, has demonstrated a pattern of disregard and failure to comply with the property maintenance code that compromises the health, safety and general welfare of the public and reduces the value of neighboring properties. 
106.4.2 Penalty Schedule for Repeat Violations. If a violation places a person into repeat offender status, the Code Official shall assess a penalty equal to triple the amount of the standard penalty assessed for a violation as established in Section 106.4, above, but shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). If subsequent violations of the code provision that the person has repeatedly violated are committed during a person's status as a repeat offender, the penalty assessed shall be not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation of the same property maintenance code provision, as determined by a judge. 
106.4.3 Chronic Violation; Process . If a chronic violation is found, the Code Official shall provide a notice of chronic violation to the chronic offender. The Code Official, however, is not required to give the chronic offender reasonable time to correct the violation, because the chronic offender, by the repeated violations, has demonstrated a pattern of disregard and failure to comply with the property maintenance code that compromises the health, safety and general welfare of the public and reduces the value of neighboring properties. 
106.4.4 Penalty Schedule for Multiple Violations Reaching Chronic Offender Status. If a violation places a person into chronic offender status, the Code Official shall assess a penalty equal to triple the amount of the standard penalty assessed for a violation as established in Section 106.4, above, but shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). If subsequent violations are committed during a person's status as a chronic offender, the penalty assessed shall be not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation of the same property maintenance code provision, as determined by a judge. 
(5)  Section 106.5 regarding abatement of violation. Replace and supplement with: 
106.5 Abatement of violation. If the owner or person responsible fails to comply with any notice and order issued pursuant to Section 107 to bring any structure or land into compliance with the provisions of this code (or any order after an appeal of the same), the Code Official may take any action as is reasonably necessary to abate the violation (subject to the applicability of any required findings pursuant to Section 108.7). In doing so, neither the Code Official, his agents nor the City shall be responsible for damage to property due to reasonable methods of gaining entrance onto the property or for damages to property in the reasonable exercise of the abatement of the violations. The Code Official may use the City's employees or contract for services to abate these violations. 
106.5.1 Interference. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with or attempt to prevent the Code Official or his agents from an abatement action. 
106.5.2 Notice of Costs . If the Code Official takes action to abate a violation, the Code Official shall thereafter provide to the owner or person(s) responsible (in the same manner prescribed in Section 107.3) a notice of costs providing: 
a.  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification; 
b.  The nature of the violation; 
c.  The nature of the work performed to abate the violation; 
d.  The abatement costs incurred; 
e.  A demand for payment within thirty (30) days from the date of notice; 
f.  A statement that the failure to pay within thirty (30) days shall allow the City to file a tax lien against the property and/or to pursue litigation for the recovery of costs; and 
g.  A statement that any interest, and any City costs necessary to recover any amounts due, including court costs, attorneys fees and administrative costs, shall be added to the outstanding balance due. Included as part thereof are the costs for both the Code Official's expense, including postage, as well as any necessary court costs and attorney's fees. 
106.5.3 Collection of Abatement Costs . If unpaid after thirty (30) days of service of the notice of costs, these amounts shall be assessed as a special assessment against the property, and the City Clerk shall at the time of certifying other City taxes certify the unpaid portion of these costs, and the County Clerk shall extend the same on the tax rolls of the County against the lot or parcel of ground, and it shall be collected by the County Treasurer and paid to the City as other City taxes are collected and paid. Assessments made under this section shall be superior to all liens except general tax liens. Provided further, that the City may collect such costs in the manner provided at K.S.A. 12-1,115, by bringing an action in the appropriate court as a personal debt, and the City may pursue both assessment and collection at the same time until the full cost, including applicable interest, court costs, attorney's fees and administrative costs have been paid in full. 
106.5.4 Impact with prosecution. The imposition of any abatement or collection action prescribed in this section shall not preclude any appropriate prosecution or penalties. Likewise, the imposition of any prosecution or penalties prescribed in this section shall not preclude the Code Official or other City official from instituting any appropriate action to restrain, correct or abate a violation, or to prevent illegal occupancy of a building, structure or premises, to stop an illegal act, conduct, business or utilization of the building, structure or premises or to collect abatement costs. 
(6)  Section 106 regarding violations. Supplement with: 
106.6 Mediation. At the discretion of the Code Official, the prosecutor, or the Municipal Court, any alleged code violation subject to prosecution under Section 106.3 may be set for mediation with the Public Officer at any time before final resolution of the matter by the Municipal Court. The Public Officer, who shall be appointed by the Mayor, shall review all charges and related issues, examine witnesses, receive evidence, and attempt to mediate a resolution between all parties of interest; provided any resolution shall comply with the underlying intent of this article. 
(7)  Section 107.1 regarding notice to owner or to persons responsible. Replace with: 
107.1 Notice to owner or to person or persons responsible. Whenever the Code Official determines that there has been a violation of this code or has grounds to believe that a violation has occurred, notice shall be given to the owner or the person or persons responsible therefor in the manner prescribed in Sections 107.2 and 107.3; provided, however, that the issuance of this notice shall not be required for second and subsequent violations of the same code provision by the same code offender at the same address within the preceding twenty-four (24) months. 
(8)  Section 107.2 regarding form. Replace requirement 5 and supplement with new requirements 6-8 as follows (Note: requirements 1-4 shall remain unchanged): 
5.  Inform the property owner of the right to appeal the notice and order within ten (10) days after the day the notice was served; provided appeals relating to violations of Section 302.4 regarding weeds or Section 302.9 regarding defacement of property must be filed within five (5) days after the day of notice was served. 
6.  Inform the property owner that the failure to comply with this notice and order shall result in the City's right to abate the violation at the owner's expense, and that failure to thereafter pay the assessment within thirty (30) days of the notice of the cost of the abatement shall result in the filing of a tax lien against the property, or the filing for judgment against the recipient, or both. 
7.  Inform the property owner that these violations are subject to prosecution. 
8.  Inform the property owner that the City is not required to issue subsequent notices for subsequent violations of the same code provision during the following twenty-four (24) months before instituting abatement or prosecution procedures. 
(9)  Section 107 regarding notices and orders. Supplement with: 
107.6 Notice of repeat violation or chronic violation. Whenever the Code Official determines that there has been a repeat or chronic violation of this code or has grounds to believe that a repeat or chronic violation has occurred, notice shall be given to the owner or the person or persons responsible therefor in the manner prescribed in Sections 107.3 and 107.7. 
(10)  Section 107 regarding notices and orders. Supplement with: 
107.7 Form of notice of repeat or chronic violation. The notice prescribed in Section 107.6 shall be in accordance with all of the following: 
1.  Be in writing. 
2.  Include a description of the real estate sufficient for identification. 
3.  Include a statement of the repeat or chronic violation or violations and why the notice is being issued. 
4.  Include a correction order stating that the City is not required to give the repeat offender or chronic offender reasonable time to correct the violation, because the repeat offender or chronic offender, by the repeated or chronic violations, has demonstrated a pattern of disregard and failure to comply with the provisions of this code that compromises the health, safety and general welfare of the public and reduces the value of neighboring properties. 
5.  Inform the property owner of the right to appeal the notice of repeat or chronic violation and order within ten (10) days after the day the notice was served; provided that appeals relating to violations of Section 302.4 regarding weeds or Section 302.9 regarding defacement of property must be filed within five (5) days after the day the notice was served. 
6.  Inform the property owner that the failure to comply with this notice and order shall result in the City's right to abate the violation at the owner's expense, and that failure to thereafter pay the assessment within thirty (30) days of the notice of the cost of the abatement shall result in the filing of a tax lien against the property, or the filing for judgment against the recipient, or both. 
7.  Inform the property owner that these violations are subject to prosecution. 
8.  Inform the property owner of the penalty imposed for attaining repeat or chronic violator status and the escalating penalties for subsequent violations while the owner remains in repeat or chronic offender status. 
(11)  Section 108.1.4 regarding unlawful structures. Replace with: 
108.1.4 Unlawful structure. An unlawful structure is one found in whole or in part to be occupied by more persons than permitted under this code, or was erected, altered, occupied, or is being maintained in violation of this code, the City Code, the zoning ordinance, or any other applicable laws, statutes, rules or regulations. 
(12)  Section 108 regarding unsafe structures and equipment. Supplement with: 
108.7 Hearing and abatement . Whenever the Code Official has condemned a structure under the provisions of this section as unsafe or dangerous and unfit for human occupancy, before any abatement or demolition may be taken pursuant to Section 106.5 or Section 110, the matter shall be set for hearing before the City Council; provided that this requirement shall not restrict or interfere with any necessary emergency measure pursuant to Section 109. 
108.7.1 Hearing Notice. The Code Official shall file a written report with the City Council describing the structure and its location and the circumstances supporting the Code Official's determination. This report may be filed simultaneously with the notice pursuant to Section 108.3. The Governing Body shall by resolution fix a time and place at which the owner, the owner's agent, any lienholders of record and any occupant may appear and show cause why this structure should not be condemned and ordered repaired or demolished. This resolution shall be published once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks on the same day of each week, and at least thirty (30) days shall elapse between the last publication and the hearing date. A copy of the resolution shall be mailed by certified mail within three (3) days after its first publication to each such owner, agent, lienholders and occupant at the last know address and shall be marked "deliver to addressee only." 
108.7.2 Hearing Findings . At the hearing, the City Council shall hear all evidence submitted by the owner, owner's agent, lienholders of record, occupants, and relevant City Officials, and shall thereafter make findings by resolution. If the City Council finds that the structure is unsafe or dangerous and unfit for human occupancy, the resolution shall direct the structure to be repaired or removed and the premises made safe and secure. The resolution shall be published once in the official City newspaper and a copy mailed to the owner, agent, lienholders and occupant in the same manner provided for notice of hearing. The resolution shall fix a reasonable time within which the repair or removal of the structure shall be commenced and a statement that if the owner of this structure fails to commence the repair or removal of such structure within this time, or fails to diligently prosecute the same until the work is completed, the Governing Body will cause the structure to be repaired or razed and removed. 
108.8 Fire or explosion. Damage to structures created by fire or explosion shall comply with the provisions of City Code Chapter 2, Article VII, Division 3, entitled "Liens on Property Damage Insurance Proceeds." 
(13)  Section 110.2 regarding notices and orders. Replace with: 
110.2 Notices, orders and hearing. All notices, orders shall comply with Section 107, and a hearing shall be conducted as provided by Section 108.7. 
(14)  Section 111 regarding means of appeal. Replace Sections 111.1 through 111.8 with: 
111.1 Application for appeal . Any person directly affected by a decision of the Code Official or a notice or order issued under this code shall have the right to appeal this decision to the Fairway Board of Zoning Appeals; provided, however, when a hearing is scheduled before the City Council pursuant to Section 108.7, any timely filed appeal shall instead be heard by the City Council at this scheduled hearing. A written application for appeal must be filed within ten (10) days after the day the decision, notice or order was served; provided that appeals relating to violations of Section 302.4 regarding weeds or Section 302.9 regarding defacement of property must be filed within five (5) days after the day the decision, notice or order was served. An application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this code or the rules legally adopted thereunder have been incorrectly interpreted, the provisions of this code do not fully apply, or the requirements of this code are adequately satisfied by other means, or that the strict application of any requirement of this code would cause an undue hardship. 
111.2 Stay of enforcement. A timely filed appeal of a notice and order (other than imminent danger notices) shall stay the enforcement of the notice and order until the appeal is heard by the Board. 
111.3 Hearing . A timely filed appeal shall be heard at the next scheduled meeting of the Board of Zoning Appeals with a quorum of the Board members, subject to the satisfaction of any necessary notice publication requirement. This hearing before the Board shall be open to the public, and the appellant, the appellant's representative, the Code Official and any person whose interests are affected shall be given an opportunity to be heard. Thereafter, the Board may modify or reverse the decision of the Code Official by a majority vote. 
111.4 Court review. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Board shall have any right authorized by State statute to appeal the decision to a court of proper jurisdiction. Unless otherwise determined by the Board, the Board's decision shall be considered final as of the date of the vote on this decision. 
(Prior Code, § 6-902; Ord. No. 1304) 
Sec. 6-54. - Amendment to Chapter 2 of the property maintenance code as published. 
    The following sections of Chapter 2 of the International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC), Edition 2000, shall be omitted, amended, replaced or supplemented as follows: 
(1)  Section 202 regarding General Definitions. Replace with: 
    Approved . Approved by the Code Official. 
    Basement . That portion of a building that is partly or completely below grade. 
    Bathroom . A room containing plumbing fixtures including a bathtub or shower. 
    Bedroom . Any room or space used or intended to be used for sleeping purposes. 
    Chronic offender . A person who has previously been issued a notice of violation or been found through the administrative appeals process or other quasi-judicial or judicial process to have violated, or who has admitting violating, any of the various provisions of this code at the same property at least three (3) times within twenty-four (24) months prior to the current violation. 
A.  A determination by any appellate body that no violation occurred shall nullify the City's previous actions regarding the specific alleged violation and, consequently, shall not be considered in establishing chronic offender status. 
B.  A person's status as a chronic offender shall terminate upon the expiration of a twenty-four (24) month period after the official date of the most recent notice of violation that triggers chronic offender status; provided that the twenty-four (24) month period is determined on a rolling basis and the period count shall be restarted upon the most recent notice of violation that either triggers chronic offender status or that occurs during a period in which the person is classified as a chronic offender. 
    Chronic violation. A violation that is at least the third violation of any provision of this code at the same property by the same person within the immediately preceding twenty-four (24) months. 
    Code Official . The official who is charged with the administration and enforcement of this code, or any duly authorized representative. 
    Condemn. To adjudge unfit for occupancy. 
    Dwelling unit . A single unit providing complete, independent living facilities for one or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. 
    Exterior property. The open space on the premises and on adjoining property under the control of owners or operators of the premises. 
    Extermination . The control and elimination of insects, rats or other pests by eliminating their harborage places; by removing or making inaccessible materials that serve as their food; by poison spraying, fumigating, trapping or by any other approved pest elimination methods. 
    Garbage . The animal or vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Guard . A building component or a system of building components located at or near the open sides of elevated walking surfaces that minimizes the possibility of a fall from the walking surface to a lower level. 
    Habitable space . Space in a structure for living, sleeping, eating or cooking. Bathrooms, toilet rooms, closets, halls, storage or utility spaces, and similar areas are not considered habitable spaces. 
    Imminent danger. A condition that could cause serious or life-threatening injury or death at any time. 
    Infestation . The presence, within or contiguous to, a structure or premises of insects, rats, vermin or other pests. 
    Labeled . Devices, equipment, appliances, or materials to which has been affixed a label, seal, symbol or other identifying mark of a nationally recognized testing laboratory, inspection agency or other organization concerned with product evaluation that maintains periodic inspection of the production of the above-labeled items and by whose label the manufacturer attests to compliance with applicable nationally recognized standards. 
    Let for occupancy or let. To permit, provide or offer possession or occupancy of a dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit, building, premises or structure by a person who is or is not the legal owner of record thereof, pursuant to a written or unwritten lease, agreement or license, or pursuant to a recorded or unrecorded agreement of contract for the sale of land. 
    Notice of chronic violation. A notice issued by the Code Official to a chronic offender for the purpose of providing notice of a chronic violation of this code. 
    Notice of repeat violation . A notice issued by the Code Official to a repeat offender for the purpose of providing notice of a repeat violation of this code. 
    Occupancy. The purpose for which a building or portion thereof is utilized or occupied. 
    Occupant . Any individual living or sleeping in a building, or having possession of a space within a building. 
    Openable area . That part of a window, skylight or door that is available for unobstructed ventilation and that opens directly to the outdoors. 
    Operator . Any person who has charge, care or control of a structure or premises that is let or offered for occupancy. 
    Owner . Any person, agent, operator, firm or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the State, county or City as holding title to the property; or otherwise having control of the property, including the guardian of the estate of the person, and the exterior or administrator of the estate of this person if ordered to take possession of real property by a court. 
    Premises . A lot, plot or parcel of land including any structures thereon. 
    Repeat offender . A person who has admitted violating or who has previously been issued a notice of violation or been found through the administrative appeals process or other quasi-judicial or judicial process to have violated, the same provision of this code at least two (2) times within twenty-four (24) months prior to the current violation, regardless of whether the violations have occurred at different locations. 
A.  A determination by any appellate body that no violation of this code occurred shall nullify the City's previous actions regarding the specific alleged violation and, consequently, shall not be considered in establishing repeat offender status. 
B.  A person's status as a repeat offender shall terminate upon the expiration of a twenty-four (24) month period after the official date of the most recent notice of violation that triggers this status; provided that the twenty-four (24) month period is determined on a rolling basis and the period count shall be restarted upon the most recent notice of violation that either triggers this status or that occurs during a period in which the person is classified as a repeat offender. 
    Repeat violation . A violation of the same provision of this maintenance code at any location by the same person for which a notice of violation has been issued within the immediately preceding twenty-four (24) months. 
    Rooming unit. Any room or group of rooms forming a single habitable unit occupied or intended to be occupied for sleeping or living, but not for cooking purposes. 
    Roominghouse. A building arranged or occupied for lodging, with or without meals, for compensation and not occupied as a one- or two-family dwelling. 
    Rubbish . Combustible and noncombustible waste materials, except garbage; including the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other combustible materials, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior, rubber, leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, crockery and dust and other similar materials. 
    Strict liability offense . An offense in which the prosecution in a legal proceeding is not required to prove criminal intent as a part of its case. It is enough to prove that the defendant either did an act that was prohibited, or failed to do an act that the defendant was legally required to do. 
    Structure . That which is built or constructed or a portion thereof. 
    Tenant . A person, corporation, partnership or group, whether or not the legal owner of record, occupying a building or portion thereof as a unit. 
    Toilet room. A room containing a water closet or urinal but not a bathtub or shower. 
    Ventilation. The natural or mechanical process of supplying conditioned or unconditioned air to, or removing such air from, any space. 
    Workmanlike . Executed in a skilled manner (e.g., generally plumb, level, square, in line, undamaged and without marring adjacent work.) 
    Yard . An open space on the same lot with a structure. 
(Prior Code, § 6-903) 
Sec. 6-55. - Amendment to Chapter 3 of the property maintenance code as published. 
    The following sections of Chapter 3 of the International Property Maintenance Code (IMPC), Edition 2000, shall be omitted, amended, replaced or supplemented as follows: 
(1)  Section 301.4 regarding general requirements. Supplement with: 
301.4 Excavation fill. It shall be the duty of the owner upon removal of a structure to fill any basement or other excavation located upon the premises and take any other action necessary to leave such property in a safe condition, including: the grading and seeding or sodding of the area; removal of dirt or mud from roads, streets, alleys or sidewalks; the allowance of proper drainage of the site; and the removal of any and all refuse, trash, debris, brush and limbs or materials from the site. 
(2)  Section 302.4 regarding weeds. Replace and supplement with: 
302.4 Weeds. All premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from weeds or plant growth in excess of ten inches (10") (254 mm). All noxious weeds, rank vegetation, vegetation subject to blight, and vegetation of any nature located in an area that harbors rodents, insects, animals, reptiles or any other creature which either may or does constitute a menace to health, public safety or welfare, shall be prohibited. Weeds shall be defined as all grasses, brush, annual plants, woody vines, and vegetation, other than trees or shrubs; provided, however, this term shall not include cultivated flowers and gardens. 
302.4.1 Notice requirements. In addition to the other notice requirements of Section 107.2, a notice for a violation under this provision shall advise that the owner or person or persons responsible is ordered to cut, destroy or remove the identified weeds within five (5) days of receipt of the notice, and that the owner or person or persons responsible may appeal this order within this five (5) day period (as prescribed by Section 111); provided, in cases where the owner is unknown or is a nonresident, and there is no resident agent, the notice shall state that the owner or person or persons responsible has ten (10) days after publication of the notice in the official City paper to cut, destroy or remove the identified weeds, or to make an appeal; further provided, the Code Official, in his discretion, may extend these deadlines when appropriate. 
302.4.2 Application of State Statute. Nothing in this code shall affect, restrict or impair the rights of the City under the provisions of State statute (as amended), including, but not limited to, K.S.A. 12-1617e and 12-1617f, and K.S.A. Chapter 2, Article 13 relating to the control and eradication of certain noxious weeds as defined by such statute. 
(3)  Section 302.5 regarding rodent harborage. Replace with: 
302.5 Rodent harborage. All structures and exterior property shall be kept free from rodent harborage and infestation. All openings in the exterior walls, ground or first floors, basements, roofs and foundations of all structures, which may be reached by rodents from the ground by climbing or burrowing, shall be closed with material or equipment impervious to rodent gnawing. It shall also be unlawful for any person to create, permit or maintain any condition that provides shelter or protection for rodents in, under or outside any structure or exterior property. Where rodents are found, they shall be promptly exterminated by an approved processes that will not be injurious to human health. After extermination, proper precautions shall be taken to eliminate rodent harborage and prevent reinfestation. 
(4)  Section 302.9 regarding defacement of property. Replace and supplement with: 
302.9 Defacement of property. No person shall willfully or wantonly damage, mutilate or deface any exterior surface of any structure or building, wall, rock, sidewalk, pavement, bridge, fence, gate, tree or other similar surface on any private or public property by placing thereon any marking, carving or graffiti; provided this requirement shall not restrict any necessary marking for governmental, utility or arborist activity. 
302.9.1 Restoration. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or person or persons responsible for the property to restore this surface to an approved state of maintenance and repair within a period of five (5) days, unless this period is extended by the Code Official in his discretion. 
302.9.2 Reward. As allocated by the City Council, the City will pay a reward up to the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to any person providing information leading to the arrest and conviction of any person guilty of this violation. 
(5)  Section 302 regarding exterior property areas. Supplement with: 
302.11. Parking and Storage of Vehicles in Residential Areas. 
1.  Except as provided for in other provisions of the City Code, no person shall, nor shall any property owner allow another person to store for more than forty-eight (48) consecutive hours, more than twelve (12) occurrences per year on any lot zoned for residential use any trailer, semi-trailer, boat, bus, camper or recreational vehicle over ten feet (10') in height, or any oversized (self-propelled or otherwise) motor vehicle (as defined by the Code of the City of Fairway Section 10-63), regardless of height, anywhere on their property. Trailers, semi-trailers, boats, buses, campers or recreational vehicles under ten feet (10') in height may be stored indefinitely on residential property behind the front building line for interior lots and behind the front and interior-side building lines for corner lots. Items must be stored on a paved surface. 
2.  Except as provided for in other provisions of the City Code, trailers, semi-trailers, boats, buses, campers, recreational vehicles, mobile homes (self-propelled or otherwise), oversized motor vehicles (as defined by the Code of the City of Fairway Section 10-63), regardless of height, may be stored less than forty-eight (48) consecutive hours not more than twelve (12) occurrences per year, in front of the front building line for interior lots and in front of the front and interior-side building lines for corner lots, on any lot zoned for residential use. Items must be stored on a paved surface. 
3.  The above shall not apply to passenger vehicles, motorcycles, bicycles, children's toys, garden carts and lawn equipment. 
(6)  Section 303.7 regarding roofs and drainage. Replace with: 
303.7 Roofs and drainage. The roof and flashing shall be sound, tight and not have defects that admit rain. Roof drainage shall be adequate to prevent dampness or deterioration in the walls or interior portion of the structure. Roof drains, gutters and downspouts shall be maintained in good repair and free from obstructions. Roof water and water from intermittent sources such as discharges from sump pumps, foundation drains, or other similar sources, excluding lawn sprinkler, shall not be discharged: A) at a point no closer than five feet (5') to any adjoining side or rear property line; B) at a point no closer than five feet (5') to any adjoining public sidewalk or road; C) within the right-of-way in any circumstance; or D) in a manner that creates a public nuisance. All drains must also comply with the Tree Protection Ordinance. 
(7)  Section 303.14 regarding insect screens. Insert: "January 1 to December 31." 
(Prior Code, § 6-907; Ord. No. 1304; Ord. No. 1661 , § 1, 12-11-2017) 
Sec. 6-56. - Amendment to Chapter 6 of the property maintenance code as published. 
    The following sections of Chapter 6 of the International Property Maintenance Code (IPMC), Edition 2000, shall be omitted, amended, replaced or supplemented as follows: 
(1)  Section 602.3 regarding heat supply. Insert: "January 1 to December 31." 
(2)  Section 602.4 regarding occupiable work spaces. Insert: "January 1 to December 31." 
(Prior Code, § 6-907; Ord. No. 1304) 
Chapter 7 - LICENSES, TAXATION AND MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Kansas Retailers' Sales Tax Act. 
    Except as may otherwise be provided by law, such a tax shall be identical in its application and exemptions therefrom to the Kansas Retailers' Sales Tax Act (K.S.A. 79-3601 et seq.) and all laws, administrative rules and regulations of the State Department of Revenue relating to the State retailers' sales tax shall apply to such City retailers' sales insofar as such laws and regulations may be made applicable. The services of the Department of Revenue shall be utilized to administer, enforce and collect the sales tax. 
(Prior Code, § 8-801; Ord. No. 817, § 3) 
Secs. 7-2-7-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS LICENSE TAXES 

Sec. 7-25. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business, trade, occupation or profession means callings, renderings or furnishings of services or products; provided the business, trade, occupation or profession is carried on from a fixed place of business or home located within the City. 
    License means the document issued by the City acknowledging payment of the required amount of occupational tax and stating the name of the license, the kind of business, where the business is located, the period which the tax covers, such other matters as may be required, and signed by the proper officer or officers. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, corporation, firm, organization, association, joint stock company or syndicate who or which is engaged in any business, trade, occupation or profession or rendering or furnishing any service for profit or livelihood and subject to the provisions of this article; provided that any individual in the direct employ of any person licensed under the provisions of this article is not a person unless that individual operates as a subcontractor, but if such individual operates or practices his skill for compensation for any person other than his licensed employer, he is a person and must pay the tax and obtain a license, if such be required by the terms of this article. 
    Tax means an occupational tax, sometimes also referred to as an occupational license fee, for City revenue upon and for the privilege of engaging in a business, trade, occupation or profession, as herein defined, without regulations. 
(Prior Code, § 7-102; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 769; Ord. No. 1312; Ord. No. 1524, § 1, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-26. - License required. 
    No person, either as principal officer, agent, servant or employee, shall conduct, pursue, carry on, or operate any business, trade, occupation or profession, or render or furnish service specified in this article, without first making application to the City Clerk for a license therefor and paying to the City Clerk the license tax as prescribed in this article. 
(Prior Code, § 7-101; Ord. No. 216) 
Sec. 7-27. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall be construed as taxing: 
(1)  The interstate portion of any business, trade, occupation or profession. 
(2)  Instrumentalities of the government of the United States, unless authorized by laws of the United States, or instrumentalities of the government of the State or its political subdivisions or instrumentalities of the government of any other state or political subdivision. 
(3)  Organizations or their employees operating wholly for charitable, religious, benevolent, fraternal, civic, educational, military, municipal, State or similar purposes, and from which profit is not derived, either directly or indirectly, by any individual. Organizations qualifying under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, 26 USC 501(c)(3), as amended, shall be exempt from any tax imposed by this article. 
(4)  Any attorney, for the occupation of attorney, if the attorney is registered with the clerk of any district court in the state, pursuant to K.S.A. 20-3127. 
(5)  Any producer or grower or any agent or employee of a producer or grower engaged in the sale of farm, garden or aquaculture products or fruits grown within the State, for that occupation, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-1617. 
(6)  The income, premiums or gross receipts of any insurance company subject to taxation under K.S.A. 40-252 and 40-2810. 
(7)  Any captive insurance company formed under the provisions of K.S.A. 40-4301 to 40-4318. 
(8)  Any mutual insurance company paying taxes into the State treasury through the Commissioner of Insurance, pursuant to K.S.A. 40-1211. 
(9)  The business of using, manufacturing, selling or delivery of motor vehicle fuels or special fuels pursuant to K.S.A. 79-3424. 
(10)  Any utility paying a franchise fee to the City, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-2001. 
(b)  The City Administrator/City Clerk may require any person, business, trade, occupation, profession, instrumentality or organization claiming to be exempt under this section to file a verified statement of the facts upon which the exemption is claimed or to provide other documentation pertaining to the exemption. 
(Prior Code, § 7-103; Ord. No. 1312; Ord. No. 1524, § 2, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-28. - Taxes levied. 
    The occupational tax hereby levied shall be in the amounts as set out for a twelve (12) month period, unless a different time is specifically stated and according to the fee schedule as adopted by ordinance by the Governing Body and on record in the Office of the City Clerk for business categories as follows: 
(1)  Retail establishments and administrative offices. Any persons engaged in any type of business or profession that leases or owns space within the City that is zoned B-1 Neighborhood Business District, B-2 Office District or B-3P Planned Business/Mixed-Use District shall pay an occupational tax computed on the basis of total interior space footage of the leased or owned space regardless of use; provided that leased departments which have a private individual exterior entrance, even though under a common roof with another business establishment, shall pay an occupational tax as though a separate business according to the fee schedule as adopted by ordinance. 
(2)  Drive-through facilities . For each drive-through lane associated with a business, the business shall pay a fee in addition to the fee as set out in the fee schedule as adopted by ordinance. 
(3)  Home occupations . Any business having its primary place of business conducted from a residential structure which is zoned R-1 Single-Family Residential District or R-2P Planned Residential District; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to convey the right to use any residential structure for a business use prohibited by the City zoning regulations including Sections 15-298 and 15-335. 
(4)  Rental properties. Any persons engaged in the business of owning and leasing or leasing apartments, duplexes, residential homes and all other rental properties for each building or dwelling leased. In the event rental property is offered for lease for the first time after commencement of any tax year, the owner-lessor or his leasing agent shall pay the tax within thirty (30) days after commencing the lease. An occupational license shall not be issued under this section to any person who has not first obtained a current and valid rental and non-owner-occupied dwelling registration pursuant to Article IV of this chapter. 
(Prior Code, § 7-104; Ord. No. 216; Ord. No. 1524, § 1, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-29. - More than one business. 
    Whenever several classifications shall be applicable to a business, the business, firm, or calling shall pay the highest classification in this article. 
(Prior Code, § 7-105; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1524, § 7, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-30. - License fee payable. 
    The license period shall be from July 1 to June 30 of each year and the fees required to be paid in one (1) annual payment by July 15 of each year. The licenses in effect at the time of the amendment of this section shall not expire until June 30. A penalty of five percent (5%) per month of the required tax shall be added in case of failure to pay the required fees when due, for each month or fraction thereof that the fees have remained unpaid with the exception that in no event will a penalty be assessed against a new business in the first year of the initial operation of the business. 
(Prior Code, § 7-106; Ord. No. 216; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1050; Ord. No. 1524, § 7, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-31. - Application. 
    All licenses shall be secured by making written application to the City Clerk which shall set forth the business classification and the interior square footage where applicable. All persons doing business or their employees not having a permanent location within the City are required to carry their licenses with them, and all persons shall present their license for inspection on request that they do so by any police officer or building inspector or their authorized representatives of the City. 
(Prior Code, § 7-107; Ord. No. 216; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1524, § 7, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-32. - Nontransferable. 
    An occupational license issued in this article shall not be transferable except when a sale of a going business has been made, in which event the buyer of the business shall notify the City Clerk of the change of management. 
(Prior Code, § 7-108; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1524, § 7, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-33. - New business, partial payment. 
    Every person commencing business shall first secure an occupational license covering the period from the date from which the business is to be started until the next succeeding July 1. The tax which would be payable on an annual basis shall be determined as provided in the fee schedule as adopted by ordinance and the tax for this initial period shall be prorated based upon the number of months or fraction thereof remaining to the next July 1 period. No refunds for business ceasing during the year shall be made. 
(Prior Code, § 7-109; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1062; Ord. No. 1524, §§ 5, 7, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-34. - Issuance of licenses. 
    All licenses provided in this article shall be issued by the City Clerk upon payment of the proper sum to the City Clerk as set forth in this article. All licenses shall be signed by the Mayor or the City Clerk or the City Treasurer and the seal of the City shall be affixed thereto. 
(Prior Code, § 7-110; Ord. No. 216; Ord. No. 866; Ord. No. 1524, § 7, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-35. - Record. 
    The City Clerk shall keep a record in which shall be entered the names of each and every person, his license, address, the date of the license, the amount paid therefor and the time when the license shall expire. 
(Prior Code, § 7-111; Ord. No. 216; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1524, § 7, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-36. - Licenses displayed. 
    All persons doing business in a permanent location are hereby required to have their license conspicuously displayed in their place of business and all persons to whom licenses are issued not having a permanent place of business are required to carry their license with them and any licensee shall present the license for inspection when requested to do so by any citizen or officer of the City. 
(Prior Code, § 7-112; Ord. No. 216; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1524, § 7, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-37. - Person arrested, fined. 
    When any firm or corporation engages in any business in this article required to be licensed without first having obtained a license as required, the manager, local agent, or party in charge may be arrested and fined as provided in Section 7-40. 
(Prior Code, § 7-114; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1524, § 7, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-38. - Payment of fine does not pay tax; civil action. 
    The payment of the fine for failure to pay the tax and secure a license shall not constitute payment of the tax nor excuse the person from making payment, and the City may proceed by civil action to collect the tax. 
(Prior Code, § 7-115; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1524, § 7, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-39. - After-hours business license. 
(a)  Licenses required . No business shall be open to the general public in the City between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m. without first having been granted a license by the Governing Body, giving such person the privilege to so operate and carry on such trade or business. 
(b)  Application for license . Applications to the City for a license to operate or carry on any trade or business between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m. shall be filed with the City Clerk to be referred to the Chief of Police who shall have the power to inquire and make findings as to the method to be used in the operation and carrying on of said trade or business, the commodity to be sold or dispensed and the hours the business shall be open to the public. 
(c)  Approval of application. After investigation, the Chief of Police shall refer all applications to the Governing Body with his written recommendations as to whether the license should be granted or denied; the Governing Body shall act upon the application within a period of thirty (30) days after the recommendation has been made by the Chief of Police. 
(d)  License suspension . The Chief of Police upon information and investigation shall have the power to suspend any license issued according to Subsection (c) of this section, if it should appear that the trade or business is conducted in a manner so as to violate the ordinances of the City, or that the commodities sold or the services rendered are unlawful, or the business or trade is operated or carried on in such a manner as to disturb the peace of the community; provided that before any suspension order shall become effective a written notice of the same shall be delivered by the Chief of Police to the person so operating or carrying on the trade or business, and that upon completion of the service, the license is thereafter suspended until further notice of the Governing Body. 
(e)  License revocation. The Chief of Police shall immediately report to the Governing Body the suspension of any license issued according to Subsection (c) of this section, and at the next regular meeting of the City Council, the license shall be reinstated or revoked by the City Council; provided that the City Council may receive testimony other than that of the Chief of Police, or the City Council may order the Chief of Police to make further investigation before acting on the matter of revocation of the license. 
(f)  Term of license . All licenses issued under Subsection (c) of this section shall expire on June 30 of each calendar year. 
(g)  Penalty . Any person violating any provision of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each and every day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Prior Code, §§ 7-201-7-207; Ord. No. 159, §§ 1-5, 7, 8; Ord. No. 1524, § 8, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 7-40. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each and every day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Prior Code, § 7-113; Ord. No. 611; Ord. No. 1524, § 7, 4-9-2012) 
Secs. 7-41-7-66. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FRANCHISES 

Sec. 7-67. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City means the City of Fairway, Kansas. Any reference to "within the City" means within the corporate City limits of the City of Fairway, Kansas. 
    Entity means any individual person, governmental entity, business, corporation, partnership, firm, limited liability corporation, limited liability partnership, unincorporated association, joint venture or trust and shall include all forms of business enterprise not specifically listed in this article. 
    Facilities means lines, pipes, mains, laterals, wires, cables, conduit, ducts, poles, towers, cabinets, vaults, pedestals, boxes, appliances, antennae, transmitters, gates, meters, gas distribution system and gas distribution facilities, together with all necessary appurtenances or other equipment thereto, or any part thereof, for the purpose of providing or otherwise facilitating any service. 
    Franchise means the grant, right, privilege and franchise by the City to provide, distribute, transport or sell a service within the City and/or to install, construct, maintain, extend or operate facilities along, across, upon, under or within the right-of-way. The grant, right, privilege and franchise shall be in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. ch. 12, art. 20 (K.S.A. 12-2001 et seq.), the City's home rule power, and applicable City ordinances. 
    Franchise fee means consideration paid in the form of a charge upon a franchisee as prescribed in the ordinance granting the franchise. Any such franchisee fee shall be subject to any applicable provisions of Federal or State law. 
    Franchisee or grantee means any entity that has a franchise granted by the City pursuant to this article, K.S.A. ch. 12, art. 20 (K.S.A. 12-2001 et seq.), and/or the City's home rule power. 
    Gas consumer means, without limitation, any entity that receives natural gas or other energy within the City through a gas distribution system or gas distribution facilities. 
    Gas distribution system or gas distribution facilities means a pipeline or system of pipelines, including, without limitation, mains, pipes, boxes, reducing and regulating stations, laterals, conduits and services extensions, together with all necessary appurtenances thereto, or any part thereof, for the purpose of distribution or supplying natural gas or other energy for light, heat, power and all other purposes. 
    MCF means a measurement of natural gas equal to one thousand (1,000) cubic feet. It is assumed for purposes of this article that one (1) MCF equals one million British Thermal Units (1,000,000 BTUs). 
    Other energy means any energy provided in a gaseous, liquid, or slurry mixture form through pipelines for light, heat, power, and all other purposes as an alternative or replacement for natural gas, but specifically, it shall not include electrical energy. 
    Reseller means a provider of service within the City whereby the provider purchases and resells the service of a duly authorized franchisee, but only where the duly authorized franchisee is already paying fees for the resold service under its franchise with the City (i.e., the resale of local exchange service as contemplated by K.S.A. 12-2001(n)). 
    Right-of-way means present and future streets, alleys, rights-of-way, and public easements, including easements dedicated to the City in plats of the City for streets and alleys. The term "right-of-way" shall not include property owned by the City outside of said streets, alleys, rights-of-way, and easements, or public easements limited in their dedication of purpose or otherwise not intended for placement of facilities (i.e., a public easement dedicated only for stormwater purposes). 
    Service means any utility or similar service to be provided, distributed, transported or sold to an entity by means of a delivery or distribution system that is comprised of facilities within the City, including, without limitation, telecommunication, cable, broadband, Internet, open video systems, steam, electric, water, telegraph, data transmission, natural gas, other energy, or any other similar service. 
(Prior Code, § 7-1302; Ord. No. 1465) 
Sec. 7-68. - Franchise requirement. 
    No entity shall provide, distribute, transport or sell a service within the City or shall install, construct, maintain, extend or operate facilities along, across, upon, under or within the right-of-way without a franchise authorizing the same, unless applicable Federal or State law prohibits City enforcement of such requirement. This franchise requirement includes: 
(1)  Entities with facilities within the City in order to provide, distribute, transport or sell service within the City; 
(2)  Entities with facilities within the City in order to provide, distribute, transport or sell service outside, but not within the City; and 
(3)  Entities without their own facilities within the City that lease or otherwise use the facilities of other entities in order to provide, distribute, transport or sell service within the City. 
Provided that this franchise requirement shall not include a reseller, or include a governmental entity that has entered into an agreement with the City pursuant to K.S.A. ch. 12, art. 20 (K.S.A. 12-2001 et seq.) regarding the use and occupancy of the right-of-way. 
(Prior Code, § 7-1303; Ord. No. 1465) 
Sec. 7-69. - Gas distribution systems and gas distribution facilities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any entity to install, construct, maintain, extend or operate or a gas distribution system or gas distribution facilities or to provide, distribute, transport or sell natural gas or other energy within the City without first obtaining a franchise authorizing the same and requiring a franchise fee. This franchise requirement applies to any provision, distribution, transportation or sale to a gas consumer within the City whether or not the portion of the entity's gas distribution system is in the right-of-way; provided that, in the event the gas distribution system or gas distribution facilities of a franchisee are used by an entity without its own gas distribution system or gas distribution facilities within the City for the transportation or sale of said entity's natural gas or other energy to a gas consumer, said entity shall be exempt from the requirement of obtaining a franchise if it reports, calculates and pays (either directly or through the franchisee) a sum to be submitted to the City for such services that is equivalent to the calculation of the franchisee's franchise fee. in such event, if gross receipts are not or cannot be reported, a sufficient volumetric rate multiplied by the number of MCF of the transported natural gas may be used in making such calculation. 
(Prior Code, § 7-1304; Ord. No. 1465) 
Sec. 7-70. - Preservation of police power; authority and applicability of regulations. 
    Any rights granted pursuant to this article or pursuant to any franchise are subject to the authority of the City to adopt and enforce ordinances and regulations necessary to the health, safety and welfare of the public. All entities subject to this article shall also be subject to and comply with all applicable Federal and State laws, statutes and regulations, and all applicable rules, regulations, policies and ordinances enacted by the City, including, without limitation, the City's ordinance relating to the use and occupancy of the public right-of-way (codified as Article III of Chapter 9 of this Code, and amendments thereto) and the City's ordinance relating to utility facilities (codified as Division 4 of Article III of Chapter 15 of this Code and amendments thereto). Provided that nothing in this article shall be deemed to waive a right, if any, that an entity might have to seek judicial or regulatory review as provided by law. 
(Prior Code, § 7-1305; Ord. No. 1465) 
Sec. 7-71. - Nature of rights granted by any franchise.
